title: i pulled threads skin after
story: Exclusive: I pulled threads from my skin after botched facelt left me streaming with bloodBarbara Bellinger, , from Weston Super Mare, has warned others not to fall for reduced price, bargain cosmetic surgery after fearing she could be permanently disfiguredBarbara has issued a stark warning to people considering reduced price cosmetic treatment Image: MakeTheHeadlinesByCarol DriverJessica TaylorReal le features writer:,  Nov | comments Barbara Bellinger spotted an advert for a £ thread facelt on Facebook and her eyes lit up.The tempting, heavily reduced offer seemed like exactly the new start for the new year she wanted. So, at the beginning of , she booked herself in. I spotted a beauty salon was running a training day, and required models with a trainer who had more than  years’ experience. At £, it seemed like a great opportunity at a price I could afford. I wanted to give myself a new yearaposs lt, Barbara, , said. But when she went to have the procedure, she claims something didnapost feel right.For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here My treatment was really painful, and it felt very rushed. I was keen to get it over with as it hurt so much. The final result felt very tight, but looked fine, she recalled. After the treatment, Barbara was sent on her way and told to take ibuprofenshe felt any discomfort. She was also told to wait six weeks to see the full results. The next day, Barbara claims she felt something snap in her face - but when she called the salon, she was told it was normal. She said: “My face felt extremely tight and painful and even chewing was dficult but I believed it would settle as they told me it would. A few days later, she felt a bump above her top lip.  When I touched it, it felt sharp and stung, like it was piercing my skin. I contacted the salon again, and was told to try and manipulate the thread back up, and to not mess with it, she said. I was so concerned I sent a video of myself doing exactly as instructed to the salon, to show them. The next day she became even more concerned when a blue thread pierced the skin by her top lip and she pulled it out. “The thread had a cog on and came out of my face! Fortunately, there was no major bleeding, but I was incredibly concerned that my face would become lopsided.” After calling the salon to complain, she claims she was told it was her own fault. Barbara added: At no point did the trainer contact me directly to check on me. She had washed her hands of the whole thing. Terried her face was damaged forever, Barbara found another thread piercing her skin, near her eye. When she tried to pull out the thread, the cog at the end got caught on her skin tissue, which caused it to pucker. By now, blood was streaming down her face as she tried to push it back in. In the end, she managed to remove the thread by slowly manoeuvring it outward. I was left with two further lumps. One by my chin and another by my nose. I feared both threads would poke through at any moment, she said. I took myself to AE who were supportive, but said they couldn’t touch it as it was cosmetic and they would not risk hurting me further. I was beside myself. The pain was so bad I contemplated buying a scalpel to cut the threads out of my face. After conducting her own research, Barbara found Save Face, a national register of medical practitioners accredited to provide non-surgical cosmetic treatments.She travelled to River Aesthetics clinic in Bournemouth, which is a training centre for Silhouette Soft threadlts - which are only available from medically qualied clinicians.After a consultation with the clinicians, Barbara was determined unsuitable for threadlting treatment in the first place due to an autoimmune condition. Dr Manning, from River Aesthetics, said: “A medical professional would have identied this immediately.  “We could clearly see the threads had been inserted superficially and had migrated signicantly since their placement. “The threads were unlike any we had seen before. We suspect they may not have even reached UK standards. “ Dr Manning added he worked with Barbara to remove as much of the thread as he could from her face - and added she was lucky not to have been disfigured by her experience. We strongly urge anyone considering aesthetic treatments to research the treatment provider and the treatment itself, he said. Three months later, when Barbaraaposs face had fully healed, she went back to the clinic for the new look sheaposd originally wanted.The clinicians used MaiLi filler to plump up her cheeks, add definition to her jawline and enhance her lips.Barbara said: “I would strongly urge anyone contemplating an aesthetic treatment, to thoroughly research everything and ask questions about the qualications of the treatment provider, the treatment modality, the products being used. Seethey are accredited by Save Face. “Don’t do what I did and be seduced by the price and the promise that someone is a ‘trainer’.Have you ever had a cosmetic procedure that didnapost go to plan  Send your stories to jessica.taylor@reachplc“Iaposm absolutely thrilled with the results now. I should have researched the suitability of dferent procedures and treatments and got a better understanding from the experts about the results that I could expect to achieve. “We now know that I wasn’t suitable for PDO threads so itaposs frustrating to think that I went through all of that pain and worry for nothing.” Comment MORE ON Cosmetic surgeryPlastic surgery" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: afghan baby boy born london
story: Afghan baby boy born in London hotel room as mum delivered without doctorA baby boy has been born swtly in a hotel room in London, with volunteer and RAF veteran Melanie Clark the only one there to help his mother, who is an Afghan evacueeA baby was miraculously born healthy despite his Afghan mother giving birth to him in a hotel room Image: PAByMichael Drummond:,  Nov | commentsAn Afghan evacuee has given birth to a baby boy in a hotel room, highlighting the cold reality of those resettling in the UK. The healthy baby was born swtly, but there was no one there to help the non-English speaking mother except for volunteers. Melanie Clark, an RAF veteran who works as a nurse, explained how she had been volunteering at the hotel in London when she was alerted that the mother had gone into labour. We went up to the room, I thought I would be maybe reassuring someone and making sure an ambulance was on its way, she said. Neither the woman nor her husband spoke much English, but a fellow volunteer with Ms Clark was able to translate. Questions and answers had to be relayed from the ambulance control room to Ms Clark and her colleague and then translated for the husband and we, and back again.What do you think of this  Let us know in the comments below At some point, Ms Clark said, it became clear that paramedics would not arrive in time and that she would be delivering the baby - for the first time in her le Ms Clark, who works at St Richardaposs Hospital in Chichester, West Sussex, told PA: I am a nurse but midwery didnapost come in our nurse training. Before the baby arrived, before its head came out, it was scary. It was scary and nerve-wracking about whether this was going to turn out OK. Without knowing the motheraposs medical history, Ms Clark was conscious that there could be issues she was not aware of. But the baby boy - the motheraposs sixth child - was born safely and swtly. But Ms Clark, who served in Iraq with the RAF, said the birth raises questions about the level of medical care available for refugees in the UK. She continued: They are registered with a GP but the level of support they have had and the knowledge of their pregnancies is very, very limited.  I just thought, I am sure it will happen again. She added that more needs to be done to help those evacuated from Afghanistan. She said: We canapost just stand by... just bringing them into this country is not enough because they are traumatised and they need some kind of future... they need to know whataposs happening next. I went to Iraq. I have seen the dficulties people face and the effects of war on people. Almost three months on from the airlt, the Home Office has said the Afghan Citizensapos Resettlement Schemeis not yet open and that more information will be provided in due course. Louise Calvey, head of services and safeguarding at the charity Refugee Action, said people brought to the UK during the Kabul airlt were living in limbo. She added: Weaposd like to offer our congratulations to the family. We hope they can build safe and happy lives in the UK. But itaposs appalling that three months after the evacuation of Kabul thousands of Afghan refugees are still living in limbo in hotels with no settled access to employment, healthcare or education. Rather than the warm welcome people were promised, theyaposre seeing the cold reality of our refugee protection system. Ministers must move quicker to get people out of hotels and integrated into our communities, where they can start to properly rebuild their lives. title: asda worker tried kick woman
story: Asda worker tried to kick woman out of shop because she was basically nakedThe shopper, named Jaiah, said she was in the Asda supermarket in the Isle of Dogs, east London, when a worker confronted her, and she called the incident the most disgusting behaviourAsda said it was not their policy Image: TwitterByWilliam WalkerNews Reporter:,  Nov | commentsA woman says she was left stunned by supermarket staff after she was allegedly told she was aposbasically naked and shouldnapost be thereapos. The shopper, named Jaiah, said she was in the Asda supermarket in the Isle of Dogs, east London, when the incident unfolded. She posted video footage of the incident on social media, which she called aposthe most disgusting behaviour.apos In the clip an employee can be heard saying aposwe can see your body almost, the manager is coming right nowapos. She claims the worker, who has not been named, told her she didnapost respect herself and that the supermarket had a policy.  He can be heard to reply: Itaposs not because you donapost respect yourself, we have a policy in ASDA.She shared the episode on Twitter and captioned the footage: So tonight in ASDA, Isle of Dogs, I was told by an employee that I wasn’t wearing enough clothes, I wasn’t respecting myself, that I’m basically naked and I shouldn’t be in there.Honestly the most disgusting behaviour. Responding to her post on social media the food giant said: Hi Jaiah, thanks for bringing this to our attention.  This is not a recognised policy at Asda and we are really sorry for the service you received. Iaposve spoken to the store manager who is addressing this incident and I would be happy to discuss how we can put it right for you  A spokesman was also reported to have added: As soon as we were made aware of this incident we launched an investigation within the store. We have been in contact with Jaiah to explain that this is not our policy and to apologise for the negative experience they had on this occasion. title: cadbury secret santa back 2021
story: Cadbury Secret Santa is back for  – and you can send free chocolate to loved onesCadburys Secret Santa postal service is back for  so chocolate lovers can send a free treat to their loved ones. Heres all you need to knowCadburys Secret Santa is back for  Image: CadburysByAriane Sohrabi-ShirazSEO Editor:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | comments Cadburyaposs Secret Santa postal service is back for  so chocolate lovers can send a free treat to their loved ones. Hereaposs all you need to knowItaposs great news for chocolate fans, because Cadburyaposs Secret Santa postal service is back for .Thereaposs no Christmas without Cadburyaposs, but what makes this even better is that you can make sure your loved ones get some for free.Last year chocolate fans might remember Cadburyaposs Secret Santa went virtual, along with almost everything  in ! This year chocolate fans will have to visit a Cadbury Postal Servicethey want to send their a yummy treat to a friend or loved one.  To make Christmas even more special Cadbury has teamed up with the Trussell Trust, a charity that fights hunger and works to end the need for food banks in the UK. Is Cadbury Secret Santa free  The best thing about Cadbury Secret Santa is that it is completely free. In addition to costing nothing, Cadbury will also donate one bar on your behalf to someone who needs to use a food bank in the Trussell Trust network. Cadbury believes there is goodness in everyone and by supporting the Trussell Trust with the help of the nation, they are helping make Christmas special for everyone this year. How does Cadburyaposs Secret Santa work  Simply choose from a scrumptious selection of Cadbury chocolate bars, and then they will send it to a family member, friend, colleague or loved one on your behalf. The Postal Service will delivery anywhere in the UK. You can choose from a number of chocolate bars, including the classic Dairy Milk as well as other exciting flavours including Winter Orange, Winter Wonderland, Oreo, Caramel, Wholenut and Fruit  Nut. How do I send Cadbury Secret Santa   In order to send off a tasty freebie, youaposll have to head to one of the popup stores which could be coming to a town near you. Here is a full list of dates and places:th November – Cardf, CW Church Way th November – Edinburgh, Castle Street th November – Anfield Stadium, Liverpool – Liverpool vs Southampton th December – London, Southbank th December – Etihad Stadium, Manchester – Manchester City vs Wolves th December – Birmingham, St Martin’s SquareUnfortunately, Cadburyaposs Secret Santa service is not virtual this year, soyou donapost live near any of these places you might have to consider a dferent option. If youaposre out shopping you could always leave a chocolate bar in a friendaposs postbox for them to find later.Alternatively, you can use the Cadbury Gts Direct website to send someone a tasty gt. To find out more head to Cadburyaposs Secret Santa website.Comment MORE ON Postal ServiceChocolate" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: christmas could ruined next five
story: Christmas could be ruined for the next five years due to Covid, expert warnsProfessor Tim Spector has warned Covid might not only ruin this Christmas but the next five festive seasons because current testing and vaccine measures are not enough to control the virusA Covid expert has warned that the virus could ruin Christmas for the next five years because current measures to control it are insufficient Image: Getty ImagesByNina Massey, PARyan FaheyReporter:,  Nov | commentsCovid could ruin the next five Christmases as current measures to control the virus are insufficient, an expert has warned. Kingaposs College genetic epidemiology Professor Tim Spector warned Brits to be prepared for Covid to cause major problems for the next five years. The lead scientist on the Zoe Covid Study app says experts now have a better understanding of the virus than last year.Scientists in  were mainly concerned about getting to the end of the year, but can now take a view into the future. Prof Spector said: And thataposs clearly turning out not to be the case, as we realise that just vaccines alone, even in countries that have got higher vaccination rates than ours, are not the final solution to this.  But we need a combination of measures. We need to extend the vaccination programme to include three shots. We also need to realise there will be breakthrough infections that are real, we now know that vaccinated people can still transmit the virus, and that is going to be running through our populations to some degree. How high we want those rates to be is highly determined by our complacency and our relaxation of some of the rules that we had in place, that last year I thought weaposre actually over the top, and now this year, I think insufficient. Speaking at an online conference for the Royal Society of Medicineaposs Covid- series, .Prof Spector says the ending of restrictions in July gave Brits the impression the pandemic had a black and white answer.  Prof Spector said: We have to realise we just have to in some way controlinto something that doesnapost cause as much loss of le, doesnapost cause morbidities, and reduce that. And to do that is a combination of the vaccines, the medicines, etc. But also we have to keep some public health measures in place to keep those numbers down - weaposre not doing that. And thataposs why for the last three months, weaposve had the highest rates not only of cases but also hospitalisations in western Europe. And I think itaposs pretty unwise for a country that has such a perilous health system - even at this stage about % of hospital beds full of Covid - at a time when weaposve got massive other health needs.  So weaposre not doing enough, we are too complacent. The Government has a sort of a black and white approach and I think the public health messaging from the Government has been appalling. He said the British approach to testing needs to move towards using a combination of lateral flow and antibody tests to pinpoint members of the public at risk of breakthrough infections. His comments came as a new study revealed the amount of under s in England who died from Covid between March  and February .  The research, published in Nature Medicine, found , young people died in that time period out of Englandaposs ,, people under the age of . Sixty-one of those tested positive for Covid- before their death.Of the ,  were due to coronavirus -gtcoronavirus - with cause of death for  being Covid, and three due to paediatric inflammatory multisystem syndrome temporally associated with the virus.Almost allof those under  who tested positive for Covid survived. Those older than , those of BAME background and co-morbidities were over-represented in the virus-related deaths compared with other deaths in children and young people. Researchers say the results will be key to guiding decisions on shielding and child vaccinations. The main iant studied was Alpha, but newer iants should be evaluated in a similar way. Russell Viner, professor of adolescent health at UCL, an author of the paper, said: In terms of what this means for us now, we donapost have updated data in this form for the last six months, although we will in the future. Paediatricians across the country believe that these findings still broadly hold - that children are at extremely low risk of death from this virus, most deaths of children with a positive test are not related to Covid but reflect the commonality of infection in the population, and that the children at most risk are those who have always been at higher risk - those with serious other medical conditions. title: christmas jumper day what charity
story: Christmas Jumper Day - when is it and what charity does it support It might still be mid-November but its safe to say we’re getting into the Christmas spirit already with internet searches for Christmas jumpers skyrocketing – just in time for Christmas Jumper Day Save the Children is asking as many people as possible to join the fun in order to raise fundsByMalvika Padin:,  Nov | commentsChristmas Jumper Day, which has raised more than £m since its launch in , gives you a chance to dig out your festive jumpers, come together as a community and raise funds to help children and families in UK and around the world. Led by Save the Children, which works to support children and families in need all year round, the event is all the more important this year.With the pandemic impacting the charity’s funds, the organisation hopes that more people will join in the fun this year to not only spread Christmas cheer but also help raise much-needed money.  Hereaposs everything you need to know about the charitable holiday. What is Christmas Jumper Day On this day every year, the charity asks that you find your most outlandish festive jumper for one day, and donate £ -or £ for children taking part in school-to their cause.When is Christmas Jumper Day   The nationwide event always falls on the second or third Friday in December. This year it takes place on Friday, December . How to take part in Christmas Jumper Day Taking part in the holiday is easy and fun. All you need to do is come together as a community wearing your flashiest festive jumper jazzed up with jingles bells or sparkles.  Over , workplaces and . million workers have already signed up this year to spread joy on the day. To take part simply make, upcycle, borrow, swap or buy a festive sweater, wear it on Friday, December  and donate £to Save the Children. Save the Children have said that £ could help “warm some tummies, save some lives, and change the future. That’s big.”You can sign up using this form on the charity’s website. How  can you get involved  It may not always be possible for people to donate money. But the charity suggests doing ious other fun activities to either raise funds or simply get involved and spread the joy. This includes running a k, going for a bike ride or any other exercise in your jumper and getting sponsored for it. You can also make a commitment to wear your jumper for  consecutive days, no matter where you are or what you’re doing. title: couple who drove 2000 miles
story: Couple who drove , miles to pick up dog heartbroken as hes stolen from carJohanna Kerwien and her fiance, Michael Fox, got the two-year-old Russian bolonka from her mum, who had taken him in after saving him from a Swedish puppy farmBjörn was originally rescued from a Swedish puppy farm in Sweden by Johannas mum Image: Triangle NewsByAndy Crick:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA couple who drove more than , miles to adopt a rescue dog are heartbroken after the pooch was stolen when they got home. Johanna Kerwien and her fiance, Michael Fox, got the two-year-old Russian bolonka - called Björn - from her mum, who had taken him in after saving him from a Swedish puppy farm but couldn’t care for him herself. So Johanna, , and Michael, , drove the , mile, five-day round trip to her homeland to collect him, and bring him back to their home in Grays, Essex. In a horrying twist, Björn was then pinched from Michael’s work van, after the pair parked up at Bluewater Shopping centre, in Dartford, Kent, on Saturday. Michael and Johanna came to the conclusion that the crooks were after Michaelaposs tools bricklaying, but then found poor Björn inside and snatched him too. Johanna said yesterday that the pair had been out in the van that morning and needed to pick something up from Bluewater. The couple nipped in to pick something up from John Lewis and were in the mall for longer than anticipated.  When they came back, they discovered that thieves had smashed their way into the vehicle. I was screaming, I just knew what had happened and then saw Björn was missing,” Johanna said. The people smashed the window and took him, they also took a laptop and tried getting into the back to steal tools. We only care about our baby that we canapost live without.  Heaposs our everything and we would give anything to have home back with us.” Johanna said their hearts were “broken”. The couple said Björn is very timid and frightened of people. Iaposm just very scared for him. He will be petried,” Michael added. Kent Police are investigating the theft, which happened on Saturday. news uk-news covid-cases-going-down--"Sajid Javid announces mandatory vaccines for frontline workersByIan Jones:,  Nov | commentsCoronavirus case rates are falling in the vast majority of UK towns and villages, new figures show.This week the number of daily Covid deaths in the UK has been close to or above  - the highest consistent total since Spring this year. In a positive sign that the pandemic may be moving in the right direction, daily cases have been slightly lower than last week. Local case counts reflect this slight move in the right direction. Of the  local areas in the UK, have seen a week-on-week rise in rates, have seen a fall and one is unchanged, Office for National Statistics data shows.  The Orkney Islands in Scotland have the highest rate with  new cases in the seven days to November , the equivalent of . per , people. This is up from . in the seven days to October .  Vale of Glamorgan in Wales has the second highest rate, down from . to ., with  new cases. Torfaen in Wales has the third highest rate, down from . to ., with  new cases. Copeland in Cumbria has the highest rate in Englandand Fermanagh  Omagh has the highest rate in Northern Ireland . news uk-news driver-last-bus-strands-crying-"Driver refuses to let teen on the last bus homeByHannah LucasMilo BoydReporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA young girl was left in a flood of tears in the road after a bus driver refused to let her on board. The -year-old had just missed hopping aboard the last service from Beverley Bus Station to Dunswell in north east Yorkshire.She pleaded with the bus driver to let her on the vehicle so she could get home, but he refused, Hull Daily Mail reported. Fortunately a police officer witnessed the encounter and came over to see what was going on. The girlaposs dad, Gary Hockney, said: She was so upset. It happened on Sunday night and on Monday she didnapost go to college. She was frightened to go on the bus because she goes on a public bus and she was worried that she would bump into this driver.  She came back on Monday and she was in tears about it and explained that was why. The teenager tried to board the East Yorkshire Bus service at .pm on Sunday, November , after visiting her friends. She claims that as she reached the bus it began to pull away. The girl stood in front of the bus while it was still in the parking bay so she was visible to the driver. But, she claims he refused to let her on and instead continually beeped the horn, flashed his lights and revved the engine while she was in tears. Can you just open the door, I need to get home, she can be heard saying in a video.  A police officer believed to have been dealing with another incident at the station came over after witnessing the incident unfold and spoke with the bus driver, who said that he could not open the doors due to health and safety reasons. Speaking about the incident, Mr Hockney said: In her words, which isnapost wrong going by the footage, the bus was still in the parking bay and as she approached it, it began to pull away. She was directly in front of the doors and in full view of the driver. He looked at her, he saw her and carried on pulling out. She started crying at one point and heaposs revving his engine, flashing his lights, beeping his horn and then fortunately a police officer in the station at the time came over and asked what was going on.  If you look at the footage, she challenged the driver and he just referred to this blunt health and safety policy. Fortunately for the girl, the police officer gave her a lt back home. Mr Hockney said: I want to draw attention to his actions but also the officers, because itaposs such a positive thing that she did, I would have picked her up but it was such a nice gesture. Having thought about it might be that the bus company doesnapost allow that sort of discretion, which is stupid. They should give their employees the confidence to make those decisions. Iaposm sure he would have let his own daughter on in that situation orhe saw somebody being chased or something surely at some point thereaposs a cut off and you show some discretion. A spokesperson for East Yorkshire Buses said: On Sunday night one of our buses was in the process of leaving Beverley Bus Station at its scheduled departure time when a late arriving passenger ran out in front of it to try to stop it leaving. For safety reasons, our drivers are advised not to allow any more passengers to board once they have closed the doors and reversed off the bus station stands, as it is unsafe for passengers to try to enter the part of the station where buses are moving. The passenger refused to move from in front of the bus, so a police officer who was in the station dealing with some antisocial behaviour came to speak to the driver, and agreed to give the passenger a lt home so that the bus could continue on its way. Our driver was satisfied that the passenger was safe, and the bus was able to continue with its journey. We’d advise that passengers always ensure they arrive at their bus stop in good time, and we have live tracking features on our website and app which you can use to ensure you never miss a bus.” Comment MORE ON Teenagers" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: exact time spot taurid meteor
story: Exact time to spot Taurid meteor shower as fireballs expected in UK skies tonightThe Taurid meteor shower is due to peak this week for people in the Northern Hemisphere. Heres how to watch the comet stream from the UKTaurid Fireball Observations in  as the two brightest Taurids fly over PolandByHarry Thompson:,  Nov | comments The Taurid meteor shower will be visible over the UK on Friday in what is expected to be a bright and long-lasting display. The meteors pass through every October and late November.A comet called aposEnckeapos causes the dazzling display. The large nature of the comet stream means there are actually two dferent parts to the shower.l The South Taurids are visible in the southern hemisphere and take place between th September and th November. Whereas the North Taurids can be seen from the UK between October  and December . Both parts of the shower are of similar visibility, as they are simply two dferent parts of the same cloud. When is the Taurid meteor shower  The North Taurids will be visible in the UK on Friday November , with what the Royal Museums Greenwich say will be a long and slow moving shower, with less than five meteors per hour.For your best at seeing as much of the shower as possible, you will want to find the darkest spot possible and hope for a clear night with little cloud coverage. Try and get as far away from any light pollution as you can and,possible, locate a spot with an unobstructed horizon. How to see Meteor shower Speaking to Science Focus, University of Bathaposs head of astrophysics, Proffessor Carole Mundell, said: “They’ll appear to have come from the constellation of Taurus, which will rise high in the sky probably around midnight to .am.” However, these meteors will move slowly across the sky, and you should be able to see them between midnight and am. The Taurids arenapost the most dramatic of the meteor showers you can spot in the UK - only travelling through the sky at a snail-like  miles per second or , miles per hour. However, you wonapost need binoculars or a telescope to see them - just a comfy chair and lots of layers.  Because of their slower-moving nature, they also provide a great opportunity to learn more about the nightaposs sky. Why are they called the Taurids  The shower earned it name because when tracing the origin of the where it seems they come from as they move across the sky, it appears asthey come out of the constellation called Taurus. They are also often called the aposHalloween Fireballsapos, due to their annual visibility over the holiday. It is thought that both the Taurids and Encke come from a huge comet that has been breaking up over the last  to  thousand years. title: fishmongers claims rival next door
story: Fishmongers baffled as rivals next door steal branding making them near-identicalThe owner of Fish Universe is accusing his neighbouring fishmongers of copying his original branding - he claims it has left not only his customers confused, but also the local councilA fishmongers claims its rival next door copied its brandingByJosh BoltonFlorence Freeman:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA fishmongers is baffled after claiming its rivals next door has stolen its branding making them near-identical.The owner of Fish Universe in Tooting, south London, claims his shop used the bright blue branding before his neighbours who then copied his design, MyLondon reports.But the owner of Fish World has hit back at the nonsense claims arguing theyaposre completely dferent. Fish World which was originally called Meat Wize previously had a red and black sign but gave itself the new name aposFish Worldapos and a brand new blue paint job after it introduced fish to its shop. Now the two stores share a similar identity - with what appears to be the same colour frontage - which the owner of Fish Universe claims has led to much confusion from customers.  Rafa Kashefi, , owner of Fish Universe which has been on Micham Road since , said: They stole everything from us. They stole the sign of the shop, the layout, the name, even the unorm!They arenapost on Google, when you search their name we come up first.He added: We are a family business that has worked hard for our reputation, for them to come along and do this is an insult. Rafa is left baffled as to why his neighbours had aposcopiedapos his branding.  He explained: We used to say aposHiapos and aposHow are youapos every day for the last three years, then one day they do this. I donapost speak to them because thereaposs no point trying to reason with a person who does that. One of our customers went in there once and asked why they did it, but they were just told it isnapost any of their business. In response, Fish Universe has adopted a new colour palette in an attempt to distinguish itself from its new competitor. Alongside the new palettes, a notice has been up on its door which reads: Fish Universe is not associated with Fish World and does not promote, endorse or support this shop.  In no event will we be liable for any special, direct, indirect, consequential or incidental damages or any damages whatsoever, arising out of the use of a Fish World service or product. We are highly qualied fishmongers, and we are passionate about fish and the environment. Fish Universe opened its doors in December  with the ambition of bringing the freshest and best quality fish to our customers in Tooting. We have stayed true to our core values, ensuring every single product we sell is the freshest, best quality available. Fish Universe is not liable for any loss arisen from either the use of a Fish World product or service. aposWe are also not responsible for the accuracy of any information advice given to you. The identical branding has even left the local council confused.  Rafa claims he was sent a fly-tipping fine after a number of items were left on the road outside an alleyway leading to both shops, however, the CCTV images sent to him by the council actually showed men he claimed were from Fish World. On the other hand, Manan, owner of Fish World and who requested his surname not be included, protested that his neighbour was simply jealous that he has the bigger fish empire. But when asked on the issue of collecting waste from the pavement, Manon declined to speak. Manan, who said he has been a fishmonger for  years, said: People are copying me, I’m not copying anyone.  Our shops are completely dferent. We added this new fish bit recently but we sell meat, they don’t sell meat. We sell other products they don’t sell. We sell African and Caribbean fish that they don’t. It’s a nonsense, they are jealous that’s all. Business is free here so for him to say that is a nonsense. Rafa, from Fish Universe, said he has been frustrated by a lack of support from Wandsworth Borough Council. He said: When I need to pay my business rate, they get in contact. When they they want to ly accuse me of fly tipping, they get in contact. But when I ask the council to help me with someone stealing our brand, they don’t want to help. As someone who pays a lot of money in business rates, thataposs very frustrating. When contacted by MyLondon, Wandsworth Council said the council cannot resolve a civil dispute between neighbouring shops. A spokesperson said: The aggrieved shopkeeper needs to seek his own legal advice on this matter. title: having covid jab losing your
story: Having the Covid jab or losing your NHS job is sadly the only way to goEnforced vaccination makes me feel uncomfortable, but frontline medical staff have a duty of care for their patients, says Eva SimpsonMore effort is needed to prove to people the Covid- vaccine is safe Image: SOPA Images LightRocket via Getty ImagesopinionByEva Simpson:,  Nov | comments It’s a shame it had to come to this. Yesterday the Government confirmed it will be mandatory for frontline NHS workers to have the Covid vaccine.With the exception of those with a medical reason not to, everyone must have had two jabs, most likely by April. Reluctantly I think it is the right call. No one should be made to do anything they don’t want to do. Butpeople don’t want the vaccination then they shouldn’t be in jobs that involve looking after some of the sickest and most vulnerable people in our society. Mandatory jabs are nothing new. Healthcare staff doing certain procedures need to have had the hepatitis B vaccine.Do you agree  Have your say in the comment section Some argue that’s dferent as people who went into the profession knew they had to have the jab beforehand, so were able to make their own choices, while this is something retrospective. But we are where we are. It’s nothing short of a miracle that we have vaccines to protect us from a virus that has already claimed the lives of , people in Britain alone. I believe in the Covid vaccines. I’m double jabbed. I certainly wouldn’t ask someone to do something I wouldn’t be prepared to do myself.  But I also have an  year old grandmother with a lung condition – she needs a machine at night to help with her breathing. Would I be happy for an unvaccinated health worker to look after her  From a totally selfish point of view I wouldn’t. I want the safest pairs of hands possible giving her care. The NHS, scientists and our political leaders need to do a much better job of explaining that the vaccines are safe and have been tested on people across the world. I feel desperately sorry for anyone who feels they will have to leave the profession over this – there are already , unfilled positions in the NHS in England. They certainly shouldn’t be hounded out of the profession. Maybe they can be found jobs where they don’t come into contact with vulnerable people. I hope before April’s deadline more workers are convinced about the efficacy of the vaccines and roll up their sleeves to have the jab. It would be a shame to lose dedicated workers when we need them more than ever. title: hero pc pants ran screaming
story: Hero PC pants ran screaming at pickaxe wielding robbers in just his underwearPC Andrew Wienands colleague now call him PC Pants after he ran bare-chested and screaming in Afrikaans at balaclava-wearing robbers who threw a pickaxe at himPC Pants Andrew Wienand tackled robbers in his underwear Image: politan Police   SWNSByGeorgia LambertImmy Share:,  Nov | commentsA hero Met police officer just two weeks in the job confronted dangerous armed robbers during a jewellery shop heist, while barefoot and just in his pants, it has emerged. PC Andrew Wienand, or “PC Pants” as his colleagues now call him, dashed out of his home when he saw what was happening and even had a pickaxe thrown at his head, narrowly missing him. He was woken up in the middle of the night by loud banging coming from outside his bedroom window in Barnes. The officer, who had got home from work late the night before, awoke at .am on the morning of May , , to the commotion. His girlfriend looked outside the window to find four masked men taking it in turns to smash a pickaxe into the bulletproof window of the jewellery shop below his flat. After she told PC Wienand to do something to stop it, he leapt up without getting dressed and went outside to intervene. PC Weinand, who had moved to London from South Africa a few years ago, said: “I woke up super groggy and not knowing what was happening, and then I looked outside and the men looked up at me right in the eye. “They were fully clothed in black with balaclavas, helmets, and gloves and they had a pickaxe. “The building was shaking as the bulletproof glass was resisting and the panic started building in me when I realised that our door was the one next to the jewellers and they might have thought this was another way in. “I got scared, and when I get scared, I get angry and fight or flight kicked in.  “I thought ‘screw it’, and ran down the stairs in my boxer shorts before yelling at them in Afrikaans - my second language. “I thought it might frighten them - along with my bare chest, pasty white body, and lots of hair. “One of the guys picked up the pickaxe and I thought they were going to come and hit me in the head with it so I thought my only chance was to run at them. “So I did, screaming, and yelling to my missus to call the police. “The guy pegged the pickaxe at my head and I jumped left - and thankfully I did because it missed me very narrowly and I would have been deadit had hit.” The -year-old managed to disarm the robber and he picked up the pickaxe before chasing the masked men off with it. When recalling the incident, he explained that there were five men in total - one in a car with the boot open, two on mopeds, and the other two who were trying to smash the glass. PC Wienand said: “When I chased them they jumped and split off to go into dferent directions. “I was actually running barefoot over all the bulletproof glass that they’d shattered but I didn’t feel the pain at the time because my adrenaline was pumping. “It wasn’t the smartest thing to do and I was very new in the police at the time. “But, I’d do it again because when you are scared you go to base instincts and I’m a fighter. “A lot of people did nothing and just watched and my colleagues said they wouldn’t have done anything - but again, I’d definitely still do it again.”  PC Weinand then warned: “If a predator smells fear then you become the prey.” Shortly after, police officers arrived at the scene and PC Wienand, who usually works in the Hammersmith area, gave them the “pull over” signal, which he learned not long before during his police training. He told the officers what had happened as other police cars went screeching after the mopeds. According to PC Weinand, the suspect got away and was “unfortunately” never caught. PC Wienand added: “Ideally next time this happens I’d like to be in unorm with a baton and a little bit of pepper spray. “I don’t live at the address anymore so I’m not actually worried though. “I’m not sureit’s heroic, probably stupid more than anything - and my colleagues give me so much hassle it’s not even funny. “It’s all good-natured banter.” After the incident took place, PC Wienand was nominated for the  Police Bravery Award and although he didn’t win, his granny was proud of his heroism. He said: “I was overjoyed to be nominated andanything it was my granny who was happiest. “She’s  and she would go down to her local coffee shop and tell everyone that it was her grandson that stopped the masked men on Barnes High Street. “I did always want her to be proud of me and that’s happened.” His granny wasn’t the only one who was proud of his actions and the rumour about what had happened soon spread high up the chain of command. PC Weinand said: “At the awards, the Met Police deputy commissioner who is really high up said to me, ‘are you Pants Man ’ “I was like oh my gosh this person is so many ranks above me and he’s calling me Pants Man. “My colleagues use that name, PC Pants or Captain Underpants - and a few of them do call me a hero. “It’s all part of why I became a police officer though - to help people.” Although he was new to the job, PC Weinand explained that he had been subjected to similarly scary situations. He said: “And, that isn’t even the half of it, I’ve had someone try to rob me on my way to work who then chased me to the police station and a guy try to stab me and set me on fire.” In light of the armed robbery, a spokesperson for the politan Police said: “ A -year-old officer was off-duty when he was awoken by a disturbance near his home in Barnes High Street, SW, at about :hrs on Friday,  May. “He realised a jeweller’s shop window had been smashed and that suspects were attempting to break in. “Acting instantly, he ran out into the street in just his boxers - he challenged them and a pick axe was thrown at him. “It narrowly missed him and he picked it up and ran at the suspects to stop them further breaking into the shop. “The suspects managed to escape on mopeds but left behind a number of weapons including a pick-axe, sledgehammer, and a chisel. “The shop window was damaged but the suspects did not manage to break in and steal any property. “The officer cut his foot on broken glass but was not otherwise injured.” Commander Sally Benatar from the South West Borough Command Unit said: “The bravery of this officer undoubtedly stopped the suspects from stealing anything from the premises. “He is a brand new officer, merely days into his role as a PC and he should be very proud of his actions. “I have spoken to him today to thank him for his outstanding efforts. “This morning’s events go to show that police officers are never off-duty and will always go above and beyond to help their community.” Comment MORE ON politan Policepolitan Police ServiceCrime" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news man-caught-camera-rolling-up-"Rochdale: Thief steals articial grass from front gardenByPaul Byrne:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA family is hoping someone will grass after a brazen thief stole their new articial front lawn. The suspect was caught on camera passing the Hendersons’ front garden with a drink can in his hand. Seconds later the plastic turf was rolled up and taken away. Daughter Courtney, , said: “My mum opened the curtains and was like: ‘Where’s the grass gone ’ “She was really confused at first and rang my dad askinghe knew why someone had taken the grass.” She added: “It’s really bizarre because it’s like the smallest piece of grass ever.” A neighbour’s CCTV captured the moment the turf was lted at pm on Sunday as the family sat in their lounge in Heywood, Gtr Manchester, last Sunday. Courtney said: “It was at around pm, like an hour after my dad got in. I was literally on the couch at the time. “I don’t think it could be someone trying to sell it for money because it’s the tiniest thing ever, it must only be worth around £ at the most.”  The beauty business owner said the thief had a distinct walk and was wearing a bucket hat. She added: “I just don’t get how no one has seen a man walking down the street with a roll of grass. “He’s got a distinct walk and he’s wearing a bucket hat. Surely someone knows this guy as there can’t be that many people walking around Heywood with a can and a bucket hat.” Comment MORE ON CCTVCCTV footageCrime" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: man cerebral palsy shows anything
story: Man with cerebral palsy shows anything is possible with astonishing body transformationSam Dobson, who has cerebral palsy, has proved doctors wrong who told him he may never walk unaided again - he is now a fitness enthusiast after working on his physique in an astonishing body transformationSam Dobson has overcome challenges to be a fitness enthusiast Image: Sam DobsonByFlorence Freeman:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA man with cerebral palsy has shown anything is possible with an amazing body transformation.Sam Dobson, , who was told he would never walk because of cerebral palsy, has shown his remarkable strength in proving wrong those who doubt the strength in disabilities, he told Grimsby Live. The lelong condition, cerebral palsy, which affects his movement on the right-hand side of his body and weakens his muscles, affected Sam as a child. His parents were even informed he may never walk unaided again. Despite the heartbreaking news, Sam channelled his inner strength to prove the doctors wrong. He decided around  years ago he would make the biggest change to his le. Sam, who lives in Huddersfield, said: Itaposs quite remarkable because it was always a constant battle to get me to do the exercises to help with my rehabilitation when I was younger. Itaposs only as Iaposve grown older that Iaposve realised how important keeping strong actually is. I told my mum and dad that Iaposd like to start going to the gym around the age of  and they were questioning it because I wasnapost doing my stretches for the rehabilitation.The Mirror is committed to more hopeful news. We recognise the news agenda can sometimes feel overwhelmingly negative.And while itaposs our job to keep you informed and hold those in power to account, we are making a commitment to also report more hopeful news. We will celebrate the people, places and movements that are bringing good into the world and, more than that, we will dig beneath the surface of important issues with the aim of finding hope.We will be firm in our convictions - but always fair-minded. By sharing solutions to problems, we can do more good and feel better about the world around us. Because we believe you deserve it. #mirrormorehopefulFollow on Twitter @mirrormorehope And follow Mirror More Hopeful on Facebook But I fell in love with fitness ever since I signed up to the gym that day. Now  years later, Sam has grown the physique comparable to an Olympic champion. But he would be rocked with bad news when his former physios would inform that gym would make his joints worse. He said: Going to the gym would make my joints worse as this is what usually happens when you have a condition like mine as it tightens the muscles further. But I learnt to develop a set of techniques to help avoid the situation. I struggle with joint weakness which is a big part of cerebral palsy. When I was younger, the doctors predicted that Iaposd never be able to walk.  When I was at school I had people assisting me but I wanted to strive to do things that my body told me I couldnapost. I later saw the physio and she said sheaposd never judge a book by its cover again. And Sam is determined to prove to all that having a disability does not and should not dampen your dreams. He said: I just want to show people that you can do lots of things despite having a disability. The main hobby I have is going to the gym and lting weights to improve my own situation by becoming stronger as a result of that. I take that in my everyday le to strive to be better and show anyone that anything is possible. Sam has now added skying to his list of achievements after doing so to raise funds for the Childrenaposs outpatients department at Diana Princess of Wales Hospital - raising a total of £.  He said: I put all my fears behind me because I knew that my efforts would raise money for a good cause and to make a signicant impact to people on the outpatientsapos ward. I had to go through something similar when I was younger and the outpatients unit helped me out massively. I really did struggle and to give back to them was incredible. Iaposve worked with vulnerable adults, some with cerebral palsy, and I used to work as a rehabilitation assistant before so I understand more than most the challenges people face. I have seen how people try to do great things to better themselves and Iaposve seen people who have overcome challenges they face every single day. title: man nicknamed the strength predator
story: Man nicknamed The Strength Predator controlled girlfriend he called his propertyAlireza Herefedoust, , met his -year-old victim online while she was studying at university and then started training her to be a powerlter, Manchester Crown Court heardAlireza Herefedoust forced his girlfriend into a controlling and abusive relationship Image: Alireza Herefedoust  Cavendish PressLtdByAshlie BlakeyAlec WhitakerChiara Fiorillo:,  Nov A man nicknamed The Strength Predator forced his girlfriend into a controlling and abusive relationship for over a year, a court heard. Alireza Herefedoust, , met his -year-old victim online while she was studying at university and then started training her to be a powerlter. The couple moved in together shortly after and the woman even acted as a guarantor for Herefedoust so he could buy a new car, Manchester Crown Court heard.However, by Christmas, their relationship started to get worse after Herefedoust accessed the womanaposs laptop and found some old messages she had sent to another man before moving in together, the Manchester Evening News reports.Michael Lavery, prosecuting, said Herefedoust accused the woman of being a liar and a cheat, so she packed up and was going to leave him, but he persuaded her to stay and things seemed to settle down.  Mr Lavery added that the following February, a woman contacted the victim through social media and told her she wanted to meet up. Herefedoust was angry when he found out his girlfriend had been contacted and made threats against the other woman. Mr Lavery explained: Concerned that he might actually carry out those threats, the victim contacted that other woman to warn her and again packed her bags to leave. But again, he persuaded her to stay, this time saying that he would kill himselfshe left. She tried to leave him a number of times after that but each time he would stand in the doorway and physically prevent her from leaving. During this period the victim was contacted by an ex-partner of the defendant who told her he had previously been convicted of breaching a restraining order which she had taken out against him. At learning of this, the defendant became angry, punching doors and kicking things. He said to her aposI havenapost killed my ex but Iaposll finish my job with youapos. An argument followed during which he threw her down onto the bed, tried to hold her down and took her phone from her.  She sustained some scratches as a result of the assault, the court heard. The prosecutor added: Following this, she managed to leave the flat but the defendant followed her and convinced her to come back. When she did, though, he became angry again and again assaulted her by throwing her around. The victim then went to stay with a friend but Herefedoust turned up at the address and sent constant messages and videos and made repeated calls to her. He even demanded he accompany her to a doctoraposs appointment, the court was told. In May , in a bid to make up, Herefedoust took the victim away for a spa weekend at a hotel but during the trip he became aggressive and prevented her from leaving their room by standing in the doorway. She agreed to move back with him but as she was about toto university for the summer term, Herefedoust again accused her of cheating on him, snatched her phone from her and pushed her onto a bed saying: Get in your corner. It won’t end well for youI don’t get into this phone. Youaposre my property.aposapos When she tried to leave, he said: aposaposYou really think I’m just going to let you leave, you won’t be able to get out of here, you’ll be in a wheelchair. He then argued with her about the car she helped him buy and demanded that she gave him money throwing a punch at her and then kicking her to her upper right arm.  Mr Lavery added: He told her she had no choice as to where she could sit and he grabbed her arm and pushed her into the bedroom so hard that she fell over. She was so scared of what he would do that she curled up in the corner of the room and was shaking with fear. The next day he lost his temper with her again and said that he would not let her go anywhere and preventing her from going to view a flat which she had arranged to see. On June , when the defendant had taken some sleeping tablets and was asleep, the victim saw an opportunity to leave so started to pack up her belongings. But whilst she was packing up her car, the defendant woke up and when she came back in he shut the door preventing her from leaving. He said that he wouldn’t let her leave. He then attacked her, ripping the bottom of her dress and demanding her credit card. When she refused he grabbed her phone and snapped it. He then held a sharp part of the broken phone to her neck and threatened to kill her, saying, aposYour mother is not going to have a daughter by the end of todayapos. Fearing that his threats were genuine she sat down quietly. During this episode, he also broke her sunglasses. She was caused bruising and scratches during the struggle between the two. At a certain point, he left the flat to go to the car and she saw her opportunity and went down to the reception area and managed to call the police. Herefedoust was arrested soon afterwards but denied allegations of abusive behaviour saying their relationship had its ups and downs.  Herefedoust admitted coercive behaviour and was freed with a ten month jail term suspended for two years. In a withering assessment, Judge Goddard QC labelled him a very weak man. She said: You have been involved in weight training and weight lting but you are a very weak man. You do not see yourself in the same light particularly against the victims of your violent, bullying and controlling behaviour. I think you have a long way to go before you behave like a proper decent man. You exploited your strength with the victim and the fact she was someone who you were training added another layer of power. I hope you desist from forming any other relationships with females you are training. I am not sureit is a good for you to be training females - in fact it probably isn’t. Herefedoust, of Carlton Road, Whalley Range, was also ordered to complete  sessions of the Building Better Relationships programme and  hours of unpaid work. He was banned from contacting the victim for five years under the terms of a restraining order. His counsel Maria Brannan said in mitigation: aposaposHe is sorry for the hurt he has caused to the complainant and for having let him himself down in this way. The defendant was a full-time competitive weight lting coach and was her trainer. This took a toxic turn and this spiralled downwards very quickly. He is now a successful weight lting coach and has trained past champions. He has spent two years re-establishing his business and he has now been in a new relationship with a woman who works as an NHS dietician. She has been supportive throughout these proceedings and it is a much more equal relationship.Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Court caseCrown courtCrimeBullying" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: massive 40ft rare whale stranded
story: Massive ft rare whale stranded on coastline dies despite major rescue missionVolunteers for the British Divers Marine Le Rescuesoon arrived at the scene and found the whale half-submerged in the waterThe Sei Whale is rarely seen in Scottish waters Image: BDMLRBySarah VestyLeonie Chao-Fong:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov  soon arrived at the scene and found the whale half-submerged in the water" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _---.jpg" data-tracking"facebook|share|top" soon arrived at the scene and found the whale half-submerged in the water" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _---.jpg" data-tracking"twitter|share|top" soon arrived at the scene and found the whale half-submerged in the water" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _---.jpg" data-tracking"whatsapp|share|top"| commentsA massive ft whale that found itself stranded in the Firth of Forth has died despite the best efforts of a major rescue mission.The Sei Whale, which is rarely seen in Scottish waters, was found on Wednesday near North Queensferry in Fe, the Daily Record reports. Volunteers for the British Divers Marine Le Rescuesoon arrived at the scene and found the whale half-submerged in the water. As they accessed the best way to get it back out to sea, the massive whale managed to free itself but was almost stranded a second time on nearby rocks. After wildly thrashing around, it made its own way out into deeper water and was monitored swimming strongly in an easterly direction.  But its body was found further along the coastline, the BDMLR said in an update on Thursday. The update read: “The Sei whale has sadly been found dead after restranding on a beach a little further up the coast. “Unfortunately the survival rate of large whales who have already stranded is quite low as there is usually a reason for why they have beached themselves. “Scottish Marine Animal Strandings Schemewill be attending to perform a necropsy on the animal and they will share their results with us to seethere was any underlying cause. “A sad ending to what was a hopeful rescue.”  In an earlier post, they described how the team had been drafted in to try to help the stricken whale. They wrote: “Yesterday, Wednesday th November , we received a callout to a stranding of a whale in North Queensferry, Scotland. “A team of our trained Marine Mammal Medics were dispatched to attend to the animal. It appeared the animal was stuck in chest-deep water and was unable to free itself. “On arrival, all our team could see was a long back and a tall dorsal fin with the odd breath from its blowhole. “From the large dorsal, plus the fact it measured .m in , it was determined to be a Sei whale. “The fact that the whale was upright in the water certainly increased its probability of survival, but the fact that it was submerged made it much more dficult to assess. “However, it appeared to be in a moderate condition and was moving excessively in an attempt free itself from the sand. “It managed to turn itself to face out of the bay, and just as our medics were exiting the water to make consolidated rescue plans, the whale made a big effort to swim out to sea. “Quickly, our medics made noises underwater in order to create a wall of sound to deter the whale from swimming closer to shore and persuade it to swim in the right direction. “As it swam off, the whale looped round to the left of the bay and almost restranded itself again, floundering on some rocks. “Just as medics were preparing to get back into the water for further support, the whale made its way into deeper water and swam successfully off into the open sea. “It was last seen headed East and swimming strongly.” Comment MORE ON Daily RecordRemembrance DayWhalesAnimals" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news meet-harry-meghans-ex-aide-"Levin: Meghan ‘doesn’t want to be told, doesn’t listen to detail’ByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov Prince Harry and Meghan Markleaposs former aide Jason Knauf has found himself at the centre of a legal battle.It comes after Meghan penned an emotional letter to her father Thomas Markle in  and parts of it were then reproduced in the Mail on Sunday the next year. Meghan sued the newspaper publisher claiming it misused her private information, infringed herand breached the Data Protection Act and won the case. But an appeal by the publisher is currently being heard and yesterday several bombshell claims were made by Mr Knauf in a court statement, including that Meghan wrote the letter to her dad knowing it could be leaked and that she and Harry did help the authors of the biography Finding Freedom. But who exactly is Jason Knauf, how did he end up working for Harry and Meghan and what is he doing now  Hereaposs what we know... Royal aide Mr Knauf originally hails from New Zealand and is a graduate of Victoria University in Wellington. He also gained a masters in politics and communication from the London School of Economics. He previously worked as an advisor to former New Zealand prime minister Helen Clark and worked at HM Treasury, where he was the press secretary to financial services secretary Lord Myners. Mr Knauf was also a Director of Corporate Affairs at the Royal Bank of Scotland before joining the royal household in .Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up.His first job there was communications secretary to the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and Prince Harry.After Harry married Meghan, he also looked after their communications at Kensington Palace. He even attended their wedding in May .Earlier this year, it was reported in The Times that in , Mr Knauf reportedly submitted an email to Prince Williamaposs private secretary Simon Case alleging unacceptable behaviour by Meghan. The email reportedly claimed the Duchess had bullied two PAs out of their jobs in the previous year. It also claimed that Meghan seemed intent on always having someone in her sights, and Mr Knauf said he had received “report after report” from people who witnessed unacceptable behaviour” by Meghan towards a member of staff.  The report was published just days before Harry and Meghanaposs tell-all chat with Oprah Winfrey and in a statement in March, the couple said: We are disappointed to see this defamatory portrayal of The Duchess of Sussex given credibility by a media outlet. It’s no coincidence that distorted several-year-old accusations aimed at undermining The Duchess are being briefed to the British media shortly before she and The Duke are due to speak openly and honestly about their experience of recent years. The Duchess is saddened by this latest attack on her character, particularly as someone who has been the target of bullying herself and is deeply committed to supporting those who have experienced pain and trauma. She is determined to continue her work building compassion around the world and will keep striving to set an example for doing what is right and doing what is good.Buckingham Palace said they would investigate the claims but it could be some time before the final report is released, The Times reports.Royal Foundation  Mr Knauf continued in his role as communications secretary before being appointed as senior adviser to William and Kate in March , when William and Harryaposs households became separate. However, in September  he was appointed the chief executive officer of William and Kateaposs Royal Foundation.Earlier this year, it was revealed he would be stepping down from the position at the end of  ahead of a planned international relocation.Royal praise In a joint statement on his departure, William and Kate said: Jason has been an integral part of our team since . We are immensely grateful for his hard work and commitment, both at The Royal Foundation and previously as our Communications Secretary. Since taking over as Chief Executive, Jason has driven positive change, making our vision for our charitable work and the causes that matter most to us a reality. We are sad to see him go but wish him all the very best in his future career.  We look forward to launching the recruitment search shortly and welcoming a new Chief Executive later on this year. Mr Knauf added: Working with The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge has been the privilege of my career. I will always be grateful for the opportunity I have had to support their leadership in the UK and internationally. The months ahead will be the busiest time in the Foundation’s history with the first awards for The Earthshot Prize and more progress on our early childhood work. We have a lot to do with our amazing team and all of our partners. Bombshell claims Yesterday, Mr Knaufaposs explosive new evidence was heard during the second day of an appeal by the publisher of the Mail On Sunday against a High Court judgeaposs decision that the publication of a letter from Meghan to her father Thomas was unlawful. Lawyers for Associated Newspapers Limitedtold senior judges on Tuesday that they want to rely on a recent witness statement made by Mr Knauf in their legal bid to overturn the ruling. Mr Knauf said in his written evidence : She also asked a specic question regarding addressing Mr Markle as aposdaddyapos in the letter, saying aposgiven Iaposve only ever called him daddy it may make sense to open as such , and in the unfortunate event that it leaked it would pull at the heartstringsapos. He said Meghan had deliberately ended each page part way through a sentence so that no page could be ly presented as the end of the letter. In the event that it was leaked she wanted the full narrative as set out in the letter to be understood and shared, he continued. Rebutting Mr Knaufaposs evidence, Meghan said: The proposition that saying that I recognised that it was possible that my father would leak the letter, albeit unlikely, is the same as saying that I thought it likely that he would do so is, I would suggest, absurd.Meanwhile, Mr Knauf also said Meghan and Harry agreed to collaborate with the authors of the bestselling book Finding Freedom. The book was described as an unauthorised biography, and the royal couple said they were not interviewed for the book and did not contribute to it.The Court of Appeal heard on Wednesday that Meghan and Harry authorised specic cooperation in writing in December  to the authors of Finding Freedom .Mr Knauf said the book was discussed directly with the Duchess multiple times in person and over email and that Meghan gave him helpful written background reminders briefing notes. He added that in an email: “The Duchess…added the briefing points she wanted me to share with the authors in my meeting with them. And, in a December  email to the aide, he says Harry wrote: I totally agree we have to be able to say we didn’t have anything to do with it. Equally, you giving the right context and background to them would help get some truths out there…especially around Markle wedding stuff… Meghan has since apologised in a statement to the court and accepted that Mr Knauf did brief the authors of Finding Freedom with her knowledge.She said: I apologise to the Court for the fact that I had not remembered these exchanges at the time. I had absolutely no wish or intention to mislead the Defendant or the Court. title: meghan markle aide regretted not
story: Meghan Markle aide regretted not giving evidence in newspaper court battleMeghan Markle won a privacy claim against the publisher of the Mail on Sunday but former communications secretary Jason Knauf says she had written a letter to her dad on the understanding that it could be leakedMeghan and Harry at the Freedom Gala on Tuesday Image: REUTERSByRussell MyersRoyal editor:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA former aide to the Duchess of Sussex regretted not giving evidence after she won her legal battle against a newspaper publisher, the Court of Appeal has heard. Meghan, , won her High Court privacy claim after a judge found the publication of a letter she wrote to her estranged father was unlawful.But Jason Knauf, Prince Harry and Meghan’s former communications secretary, claimed she had written the letter on the “understanding that it could be leaked”, according to a witness statement released on Wednesday.Today the court heard a source close to Mr Knauf said he regretted not giving a statement to lawyers for Associated Newspapers, publisher of the Mail on Sunday, before the High Court case. Mr Knauf worked for the Sussexes until March  before becoming CEO of Prince William and we Kate’s Royal Foundation, which he is due to leave at the end of the year.  Keith Mathieson, representing the publisher, told appeal court judges it was only in July this year, months after Meghan’s High Court triumph, that Associated Newspapers had “received information from a confidential source to the effect that Mr Knauf now regretted not providing a witness statement to us”. He added: “Mr Knauf was plainly a central figure in the events he describes. “He was a senior and trusted member of the royal household staff and he continues to occupy an important position.  “His witness statement is measured in tone and he has been careful not to include evidence of matters beyond his own personal knowledge. Given the high-profile nature of this litigation and the likelihood of his evidencebeing widely reported, as well as the position he holds, it is hardly conceivable that he would say anything he did not believe to be true and I know of nothing in his evidence which is subject to any reasonable challenge.” Meghan sued Associated Newspapers Limited over five articles that reproduced parts of a “personal and private” letter she wrote to her father.  Lord Justice Warby gave his High Court ruling in a summary judgment, avoiding the need for a trial. But ANL says the case should go to a trial on Meghan’s claims including breach of privacy and . Andrew Caldecott QC, representing ANL, told the court yesterday that the letter to Thomas Markle from Meghan was “not a loving letter, not a generous letter”, contrary to how it was presented.  Justin Rushbrooke QC, for Meghan, previously described the case as “very straightforward” and said her human rights were “triply engaged” by the publication of part of the letter. In her written evidence to the Court of Appeal, Meghan denied she thought it likely that her father would leak the letter, but “merely recognised that this was a possibility”. She said: “To be clear, I did not want any of it to be published, and wanted to ensure that the risk of it being manipulated or misleadingly edited was minimised, were it to be exploited.”  Sir Geoffrey Vos, sitting with Dame Victoria Sharp and Lord Justice Bean, will give their ruling at a later date. Meghan sued Associated Newspapers Limited , which is also the publisher of MailOnline, over five articles that reproduced parts of a personal and private letter to her father. She won her case earlier this year after Lord Justice Warby ruled that ANLaposs publication of Meghanaposs letter to her father was unlawful in a summary judgment, avoiding the need for a trial.  The challenge, launched in the Court of Appeal over the last three days, argued the case should go to a trial on Meghanaposs claims including breach of privacy and . Andrew Caldecott QC, representing ANL, told the court on Thursday that Mr Markle faced nasty and untrue allegations in an article published by People magazine in the US and there was a public interest in correcting them. He added that the letter to Mr Markle from Meghan was not a loving letter, not a generous letter, contrary to how it was presented in the People article. The barrister continued: When we come to the very first allegation about cold-shouldering her at the wedding... this allegation is demonstrably , we say. Justin Rushbrooke QC, for Meghan, previously described the case as very straightforward and said her human rights were triply engaged by the publication of part of the letter. He said: This was a letter of which extensive contents, about half of it, were first published by the defendant without the consent of the complainant, or even notication.  In her written evidence to the Court of Appeal, Meghan denied she thought it likely that her father would leak the letter, but merely recognised that this was a possibility. She said: To be clear, I did not want any of it to be published, and wanted to ensure that the risk of it being manipulated or misleadingly edited was minimised, were it to be exploited, she continued. Sir Geoffrey Vos, sitting with Dame Victoria Sharp and Lord Justice Bean, said they will take time to consider their decision and give their ruling at a later date.
