In Musselburgh, she was an adult helper with the th Musselburgh Brownie pack.Frances said that when she moved to Musselburgh after she married, and as a new mum, she found friendship with the guild, which had a membership of nearly  in the s. She also enjoyed helping to arrange outings and Christmas meals over the years.

title: hound-music-causing-stir-gullane
story: Bill Hudson, of Muirfield Steading, adopted Border collie Lottie when his previous pet, Roxy, passed away.And when Lottie proved to be something of a mischief-maker, chewing through his shoes, his work notes and two sets of headphones, Bill decided to harness her energy with the power of music.He told the Courier: ldquoShersquos absolutely running me ragged!ldquoBut I was watching this programme that showed a Border collie that had been trained to get a beer from the fridge.ldquoAnd I thought,I could train a dog to do something like that, shersquod be doing something shersquos born to do ndash be a sheepdog.Bill Hudson and Lottie the puppyBut rather than fetch beer, Lottie is being trained to sing the blues.Bill, , explained: ldquoShersquos not quite got the hang of it yet but shersquos getting there, singing at the right times.ldquoShe managed to play a chord on the guitar ndash I was strumming away and she came up and started twanging the strings with her teeth.ldquoAnd I thought, well, thatrsquos not a bad note, actually!ldquoI do recordings at home and Irsquove looped one of her barks, and Irsquom trying to record her, because you can get any sound and then use it.ldquoShersquos got potential.And Lottie is in safe musical hands, as Billrsquos uncle was William Blezard, musical director to Noeumll Coward, Marlene Dietrich and Joyce Grenfell.Bill Hudson and Lottie the puppy.Bill said: ldquoHe also worked with Sir Laurence Olivier, wrote film music for Pinewood, and the music for BBCrsquos Play School, with Johnny Ball and Brian Cant.Bill, a freelance sub editor by day, is himself a musician, playing open mic nights and writing, producing and selling music. He said: ldquoI stream it on Spoty and SoundCloud too. It gets played anywhere from Egypt to Toronto ndash things Irsquod forgotten Irsquod even written!Gullane residents should be on the lookout for a carol-singing Lottie this Christmas!

title: volunteer-efforts-never-ever-forgotten
story: A town resilience group set up to help vulnerable people in the national lockdown last year saw volunteers deliver hot meals, collect shopping and prescriptions, and even walk pets and maintain gardens.Jack Worden, a member of the townrsquos community council, took time to praise fellow community councillor Rab Moran, who also volunteers for the townrsquos Our Community Kitchen and Blooming Haddington.Mr Worden said: ldquoPeople who know what you do really appreciate the contribution you make to the town.However, Mr Moran also stressed that it was a team effort.Speaking at a recent meeting of the community council, he added: ldquoThere are a lot of other people who do a hell of a lot of work as well.ldquoPat Lemmon and all those people in the resilience group did amazing work and they should never, ever be forgotten.

title: lottery-funding-community-connections-group
story: North Berwick Coastal Community Connections , launched in , was set up to identy those in the community who were experiencing loneliness and social isolation, with a view to befriending them, building their confidence and helping them make connections.Until now funded by North Berwick Trust and East Lothian Councilrsquos One Council Funding, it reaches out to people in Aberlady, Ballencrieff, Dirleton, Drem, Fenton Barns, Gullane, Kingston, North Berwick and Whitekirk.In March , the project had to adapt to the pandemic, with many of its members shielding.Project officer Carol Stobie developed befriending and lsquobuddy walksrsquo services, as gatherings were forced to come to a halt.Robert Burgon, NBCCC co-chair, said: ldquoWe are delighted that the project has received this support and recognition.ldquoThere is possibly even more need than ever for a project of this nature as so many people in our community have experienced the long-lasting impact of the pandemic.ldquoWe look forward to developing our services as we address social isolation and loneliness, across all age groups, in the coastal ward.Carol added: ldquoWersquore absolutely thrilled that funding has been secured.ldquoItrsquos been a tough  months, with many of our members struggling with greater isolation than ever, and new referrals steeply increasing over this time.ldquoNow we can plan to reinstate some of our original core face-to-face work, including Scone Cafe at the Abbey Church Hall, and to reopen our partnership activities with many other community groups.ldquoThis includes a lsquocompassionate neighboursrsquo project to support people with a terminal diagnosis, in partnership with North Berwick Compassionate Communities.ldquoWersquoll also be able to sustain our newer one-to-one services, with befriending and buddy walks for the most vulnerable members.ldquoWersquore hoping to recruit a third team member for administration and communications tasks.To find out more about NBCCC, contact Carol on   or nbc-communityconnections@outlook

title: recycling-first-boosted-top-accolade
story: Recycling First, which has been running for more than  years, has been successful in being recertied by Revolve, the national reuse quality standard offered by Zero Waste Scotland.The Macmerry-based organisation, which offers used items such as household furniture and white goods at competitive prices, first achieved Revolve certication in , gaining national recognition as an organisation encouraging more people to consider buying used goods.Revolve aims to increase reuse by improving professionalism, customer experience and visibility of reuse organisations.Tom Logan, the project manager at Recycling First, was delighted to receive the recognition.He said: ldquoThe high standards we maintain mean we can be sure our customer experience is now at a level which rivals high street shopping.Iain Gulland, chief executive at Zero Waste Scotland, highlighted the importance of reusing goods.He said: ldquoWe want to increase the appeal of reuse, develop a sector of customer-focussed organisations selling high-quality products, and increase shoppersrsquo confidence in buying previously owned goods.ldquoThis will not only help Scotland make the best possible use of the resources we have, but it will also generate income and jobs for the local economy from goods that would otherwise have cost money to dispose of.

title: former-haddington-aldi-store-split-three
story: The supermarket giant moved from its long-standing home off Whittingehame Drive to Haddington Retail Park at the end of September.Now, permission has been given to Ediston Haddington Ltd to make changes to the former supermarket.Plans approved by East Lothian Council show the building being split into three storage and distribution units.Businesses for the units have not been named but each unit will also have a counter for trade and retail sales.East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department said it was ldquonot unusual for a storage and distribution unit to operate a retail trade counter, which will make up only a small section of the units. A series of new access points will also be created.Aldi, which was based off Whittingehame Drive for nearly  years, announced it would be moving from the site last year.Now, the supermarket chain is based on the western edge of Haddington, alongside Home Bargains, The Food Warehouse and Costa Coffee.There is a vacant unit on the site, while plans have also been approved for a petrol station.

title: ross-high-school-head-pupils-vow-build-back-covid
story: The coronavirus pandemic saw exams scrapped and pupils learning virtually.With youngsters now back in the classroom, Cameron MacLennan, Ellie McMillan, Sadie Glynn and Anya Martin are looking forward to working together for the next six months to overcome any obstacles.Construction work to extend the Tranent school is also under way while its community bounces back from the coronavirus pandemic.Seventeen-year-old Anya said the mental health of pupils and the recovery from Covid- were both important issues to focus on.The S pupil was one of a number of students to put their name forward for the head pupil role.Each student had to make a video outlining three priorities to focus on over the coming year.An interview then took place before Cameron, Ellie, Sadie and Anya secured their positions.Anya was also keen to build on inclusivity with ASN pupils and was looking forward to the year ahead after a challenging  months.The pupil said: ldquoA lot about school is the social aspect, seeing your friends every day, talking to lots of people and that has not been able to happen.ldquoFor S as a year, the year has been brought together.Anya, who hopes to go on and study medicine, was keen to build on that closeness and ldquomake sure everybody has a good final year.She added: ldquoIt has been hard for everyone in the past few years.ldquoWe want to make sure everybody is enjoying it.The keen hockey player has been involved in a number of dferent aspects of school le and had been keen to be a head pupil in her final year.She said: ldquoThroughout school, I was always involved in a lot of things. I was junior leader and that led me on to becoming a prefect.ldquoIt is always a thing I wanted to do and I have always been quite involved with the school.Paul Reynolds, headteacher at the secondary school, congratulated the four head pupils on their selection.He said: ldquoThese amazing four pupils were chosen after a very rigorous selection process including applications, video presentations, pupil and staff votes, and formal interview.ldquoTo say I am proud of them is an understatement.ldquoAll four have lived and modelled the school values of positivity, respect, integrity and perseverance throughout their entire school career and are wonderful role models to all our pupils here.ldquoThey have grasped the many opportunities available to them throughout their time here at Ross High, including participation in many sports, Duke of Edinburgh, volunteering in the ASN department and much, much more.ldquoIrsquod like to congratulate them and look forward to working with them closely in this lsquoYear of Rebuildrsquo at Ross High School.

title: first-step-project-offer-christmas-essentials-families-need
story: They include Christmas presents for children, childrenrsquos winter clothing, festive food and toiletry essentials.Referral forms are available by emailing projectmanager@firststepmusselburgh, visiting its website at www.firststepmusselburgh or popping into its premises at  Galt Avenue.All forms must be ed by November .First Step is a community project for families with young children, funded by East Lothian Council and other funding bodies.It was set up in  by a group of local parents who wanted somewhere safe and comfortable where they could meet and their children could play.The project has developed its services to meet local needs while continuing to be managed by a community-led management committee and employing a staff team to support local families.

title: details-remembrance-day-parade-confirmed
story: Irene Tait, group chair, said: ldquoWe have taken this decision for safety reasons.ldquoIt was felt to have so many people in a small area, at this present time, would not be advisable.ldquoHowever, this should not deter people from going to the memorial to lay a wreath or cross on the th, th or indeed any time.ldquoThe Remembrance Sunday parade will still go ahead, leaving the Old Town Hall at .am to walk up to St Michaelrsquos Parish Church, Inveresk, where a service of remembrance will be held.ldquoThe parade will leave the war memorial at St Michaelrsquos Church at .pm to walk back to the town hall, where the parade will stand down.

title: compass-schools-generous-harvest-donation-day-centre
story: Children and staff at the townrsquos The Compass School celebrated the annual harvest with a series of class thanksgiving assemblies.Each assembly looked at how harvests were celebrated throughout the world and focused on the importance of sharing with others.The school, on Haddingtonrsquos West Road, made its annual harvest thanksgiving appeal and a huge collection of tins and packets of food was brought into school by children, parents and staff.The gts were then taken to Haddington Day Centre by primary seven children and staff for distribution to the elderly visitors to the centre.The children could only make a short visit to the centre but were able to say hello from a distance to the clients in attendance there, and even sing Happy Birthday to one of the clients celebrating her special day.Mark Becher, headmaster at The Compass, was pleased to see the connection between the school and the day centre continue.He said: ldquoThe children have spent time considering how important the harvest is to people around the world, with festivals often being held to celebrate each countryrsquos harvest, with the time of year when this takes place ying around the globe.ldquoIn every country, sharing what one has with others forms an important part of each harvest celebration.ldquoEach year, the school has a harvest collection and we have been very pleased to make gts of these to the elderly in the community through the day centre in Haddington.ldquoWe have a strong link with the day centre and it is great for the youngest members of the community to be able to have the opportunity to help the older citizens of the town.ldquoWith the day centre being closed to all visitors last year, it was good to be able to say hello to some of the clients on our visit this time and convey our best wishes to them and their fellow clients.

title: opera-east-lothian-ready-sing-live
story: Opera East Lothian last performed at the beginning of  and was devastated when its Easter charity concert and following performances were cancelled due to the coronavirus pandemic.The musical company is now back with an evening of operatic favourites, performing at The Strawberry Barn, Thistly Cross, near West Barns.John Marshall, music director, said: ldquoThe chorus cannot wait to sing to a live audience again.ldquoWe would normally be performing an opera in November to around  people but we are keeping our concert very informal and low key, with safety in mind.ldquoWe are also excited to be at The Strawberry Barn, presenting our concert in a cabaret style for the first time.Opera East Lothian will also host a raffle on the night, with prizes including an NB Gin tour, Sunday lunch at La Potiniegravere in Gullane and a one-night stay at The Plough Inn, Leitholm, in the Scottish Borders.The evening starts at .pm on Saturday .For more information, visit www.operaeastlothian

title: destiny-project-using-football-help-tackle-poverty
story: The Destiny Project, co-ordinated and created by Prestonpans Community Council vice-chairman Andrew Stevenson, provides support and advocacy for children and young people in East Lothian.The Destiny Cup, a five-a-side football tournament open to all organisations in East Lothian and Edinburgh, will start at am on November  at the Pennypit in Prestonpans.The project has partnered with Street Soccer Scotland to send a ldquoclear message that poverty is something that impacts lives within our communities.Andrew said: ldquoTogether we can raise the awareness of mental health and poverty within our communities.ldquoMany thanks to Street Soccer Scotland for the support and encouragement.

title: covid-scotland-over-50s-can-book-booster-mid-november
story: The booster scheme means that certain groups will get a third dose of the Covid vaccine, in an attempt to boost immunity to the virus throughout winter.Government officials around the UK have been urging people to get their booster jags as hospitalisations with Covid begin to creep up.And with the increased circulation of colds, flus and viruses during the winter months, getting vaccinated could help to reduce load on the NHS.Heres what you need to know about who can get the booster jab and when you can book it...Over-s in Scotland will be invited to book the Covid booster online from mid-November.So far, booster vaccines have been given to people in care homes and invites have been sent to those over- and people who are clinically vulnerable.Front care health workers have also been invited to book their Covid booster jabs on the NHS inform Scotland website.Over-s are also eligible for the booster jag, and the NHS Scotland website states that they will be able to book online from mid-November.Adult carers and unpaid carers aged + will also be able to book online from mid-November.The following groups are eligible for the booster vaccine in Scotland:All over-s who wereseverely immunosuppressed at the time of their first or second jab, including those with leukaemia, advanced HIV and recent organ transplants, will also receive a third dose of the vaccine, however this is independent from the booster scheme.

title: send-letters-santa-royal-mail-year--
story: Theres no need to try and sendletters up the chimney, just pop it in a post box instead.For -years, Royal Mail has been helping hundreds of thousands of children post their letters to Santa.Heres how you can send Santa letters this year...You can send your letters to Santa this year at the address:Santa Father Christmas,Santarsquos Grotto,Reindeerland,XM HQLetters should be sent by Friday December  to ensure time for response.Make sure to attachfull name and address so senders can receive a reply from Santa.The card from Santa will include a special note from the man himself and a recipe for a gingerbread Buddy the elf recipe.If you cant wait for the response, the card can be downloaded from the Royal Mail website.Royal Mail is encouraging customers to shop early and post early for Christmas this year.Its latest recommended posting dates for mail to arrive in time for Christmas are:Saturday  DecemberTuesday  DecemberThursday  December

title: council-workers-get-extra-day-off-next-year-queens-platinum-jubilee
story: East Lothian Councilrsquos Labour administration cabinet this week agreed to make Friday, June , a public holiday for all its employees next year.However, while some local authorities are also making Thursday, June , an official holiday, East Lothian workers will not be automatically given the four-day weekend.The UK Government advised councils to move their official May Bank Holiday to Thursday, June , to create the extended holiday.At a meeting of East Lothian Councilrsquos cabinet this week, members were reminded their workers do not get a May Bank Holiday so it cannot be moved to June.Instead, the Labour administration was told staff would beldquoencouraged to take a dayrsquos annual leave to extend the celebrations.Morag Ferguson, head of corporate support, told cabinet: ldquoAs the council does not recognise a fixed May Bank Holiday now, those staff who wish to use one of their annual leave days for the Thursday will be encouraged to do so and managers will be asked to facilitate this where possible.The cabinet agreed to make Friday, June , an extra public holiday for all staff, including teachers, next year.Councillor Jim Goodfellow urged community councils and area partnerships to take the initiative in planning local parties and celebrations across the county.He said: ldquoThis is an event of signicant importance and I am sure there are iniduals and groups within East Lothian who will wish to organise something to mark this day, perhaps with celebrations or street parties.

title: dunbar-schoolgirl-presents-poppy-poem-great-uncles-memory-towns-legion
story: Kirsten Goughrsquos poignant poem, Irsquove Been The Poppy, attracted national interest last year.Youngsters at Dunbar Primary School were studying the Second World War, in which Kirstenrsquos great uncle Cecil Thomas Dundas died.The -year-old was killed when merchant navy ship SS Jumna ndash on which he was rd officer ndash was shelled by the German heavy cruiser Admiral Hipper on Christmas Day .Ahead of this yearrsquos preparations to mark Remembrance Day, Kirsten and her mum Carol were invited to attend a veteransrsquo breakfast meeting organised by Dunbar Legion Poppy Appeal Team.The group has delivered collection cans and boxes throughout the town for this yearrsquos commemorations.To mark  years of the poppy, Kirsten recited her poem to the gathered veterans.She also presented a framed copy, specially printed on school letterhead, to Dunbar Legion Poppy Appeal team leader Sharon Kaszuba.The story attracted interest from the John OrsquoGroats Journal, as well as the University of Southampton, which has archives on the RRS Discovery .

title: east-lothian-remembrance-events-2021-details-commemorations-around-county
story: Remembrance services were scaled back last year in the face of the coronavirus pandemic.Various restrictions are still in place but services are being held in a number of towns and villages.Provost John McMillan said he was glad some Remembrance events couldthis year.He added: ldquoIt is really important to remember and people remember in their own inidual ways.While most communitiesrsquo events are on Sunday, the occasion will be marked in West Barns on Saturday. Anyone attending should head to the villagersquos war memorial for .am, with the Rev Brian Hilsley, interim moderator and locum at Belhaven Parish Church, giving a brief address at .am. The wreath-laying will then take place and refreshments will be available in West Barns Village Hall.In Haddington on Sunday, St Maryrsquos Parish Church is holding two services. There will be the usual informal all-age service at .am, and at .am an in-person, ecumenical service of Remembrance. Members of the congregations of other churches in the town will join with invited representatives of community groups.A spokesperson for St Maryrsquos said: ldquoBecause our capacity is much reduced, there will be limits on the number of people who can attend in-person. As it was in , the service will be livestreamed.To book a place, text or call   -am or -pm tomorrow .A wreath-laying takes place at the townrsquos war memorial at .am, while wreaths will also be laid in Athelstaneford and at the Ferguson Memorial in Haddington.In North Berwick, St Andrew Blackadder Church hosts a service at .am on Remembrance Sunday. Participating organisations will hold a parade to the church, led by North Berwick Pipe Band, leaving Imperial car park at about .am. After the service, there will be a parade to the war memorial, where the Act of Remembrance and wreath-laying ceremony will take place at about noon.In Dirleton, Remembrance Day will see the rededication of the villagersquos war memorial, which has been restored . The memorial service starts at .am at the monument, led by the Rev David Graham Sir Hew Dalrymple will also give a short address and music will be provided by Lyle Crawford, a senior member of North Berwick Pipe Band.Aberlady will have a short service at the war memorial at am and people are being asked to assemble at .am. There will be representatives from Territorial Army and Marine Commandos, community organisations, church, community councillors and Scouts. There will then be a service in Aberlady Parish Church at .am, taken by visiting minister the Rev John Gordon.Kaye MacAskill, church treasurer, said: ldquoNumbers are still restricted in church, so wersquore not able to have groups of unormed organisations. Itrsquos a small representative group from each of them. Some members of the public will be able to come into church but we canrsquot have a full church this year.In Gullane, there is an lsquoactiversquo Remembrance at the villagersquos war memorial at am on Sunday. Refreshments are available at The Watchman Hotel afterwards.In Dunbar, tea and coffee will be served at Dunbar Royal British Legion from am. The parade of organisations will make its way from High Street to the townrsquos war memorial on Marine Road at .am before a service is held at am. The organisations then make their way back into the town centre.A short service of remembrance will be held at the war memorials beside Athelstaneford Parish Church and Stenton Parish Church at .am on Sunday.At Prestonkirk Parish Church in East Linton, there will be a joint service for all three churches in the parish ndash Stenton, Athelstaneford and Prestonkirk ndash at .am.Meanwhile, in Prestonpans, a Remembrance parade will go ahead as normal, with a socially distanced crowd in attendance. The parade marches off from the Legion at .am along Rope Walk to Redburn Road, North Grange Avenue and down West Loan to the war memorial. An upgrade to the square that surrounds the war monument is under way but space will be made to ensure the ceremony can take place.In Cockenzie and Port Seton, a similar parade takes place on Sunday, leaving the Legion at .am and arriving at the village green for .am. The service will be followed by a two-minute silence at am before parading to Cockenzie Old Parish Church. Following a service at the church, the parade willto the Legion, where at about .pm a salute and silence, followed by a lament from the pipe band, will take place.In Longniddry, a church service takes place at Longniddry Parish Church on Sunday at .am.In Tranent, a parade starts from East Lothian Co-operative Bowling Club, down Ormiston Road, High Street, Church Street, Winton Place and High Street to Tranent Parish Church for a service at .am.In Elphinstone, a parade begins at .pm from Elphinstone Minersrsquo Club to Main Street for a gathering at the war memorial, before ing to the minersrsquo club for .pm.In Ormiston, a remembrance service takes place at the village church at .am, while two wreaths will be laid at the side of the building. Following the service, a walk to the memorial will take place where a further two wreaths will be laid.Pencaitlandrsquos church holds a service at .am, followed by the community act of remembrance at the war memorial at noon.In Musselburgh, there will be no official service on Remembrance Sunday at the Mall Fountain but a parade will leave Musselburgh Town Hall at .am to walk to St Michaelrsquos Church, Inveresk, for a service of Remembrance.In Wallyford, a service takes place at St Clementrsquos Church at am. Wreaths will be laid in the church garden at am.

title: section-a1-closed-overnight-repairs
story: Overnight repairs are being carried out on the eastbound carriageway of the road between Abbotsview Junction and East Linton.BEAR Scotland is carrying out the work from pm to am, with the eastbound section of road closed between those times.Traffic will come off the A at the Abbotsview Junction and follow the A before rejoining the A at Thistly Cross Roundabout.The ersion is expected to add about three minutes to the journey.Tommy Deans, BEAR Scotlandrsquos south east network manager, said: ldquoThese repairs will enhance safety for motorists.

title: coastguard-lifeboat-called-kayakers-get-difficulty-off-cockenzie
story: North Berwick and Dunbarrsquos Coastguard teams received a call shortly before noon and were joined by Kinghornrsquos RNLI volunteers.Just prior to the arrival of the RNLI crew at about .pm, it was confirmed that the two kayakers had made it ashore but one kayak was still drting east.A spokesperson for Kinghorn RNLI said: ldquoWhilst personnel from North Berwick Coastguard Rescue Team and Dunbar Coastguard attended to the paddlers, we tried to recover the kayak.ldquoAt this point, it became apparent that two other members of the group had continued to Longniddry and their welfare was unknown.ldquoThe leboat was tasked to check up on them but it was soon confirmed that they were safely ashore.ldquoWe then ed to locate the kayak, which by now had drted east of Port Seton onto rocks.ldquoA crew member went ashore to assist Coastguard personnel recover the delicate kayak, which had sustained damage and had filled with water. It was successfully emptied and taken to the harbour for collection.

title: see-bonnie-babies-couriers-1-000-competition
story: In todays Courier print edition, we feature - for the last time - all the cute kids in the running for the pound first prize.Theyre so sweet that we just had to share them online too!The winner is the little one with the most votes after the final round - and votes can only be cast using the coupon published in this weeks Courier.So pick up a copy today! Remember, pound goes to the runner up and pound the family of the child in third. Get voting now!

title: put-christmas-tree
story: The date for putting up the Christmas tree tends to y from family to family, with some opting for an early start to the festivities, while others wait right until the last minute.But did you know theres a traditional date for putting up your tree Heres everything you need to know about when you should be putting up your Christmas tree...According to tradition in the UK, you should put your Christmas tree up around the beginning of advent, which is four Sundays before Christmas.This year, advent will start on November , however lots of people will choose to wait until December .Roman Catholic tradition on the other hand is at the other end of the spectrum - waiting until Christmas eve to put up the tree.The Queen finishes "dressing" her tree on Christmas eve, with all the members of the Royal family joining in as a festive family activity.While there are dferent traditions, it is of course completely up to you when you choose to put up your tree and start celebrating the festive season!Again, according to tradition, you should take your tree down on the th day of Christmas, which is January .The first day of Christmas is unsurprisinglyDecember  and traditionally is followed by  further days of celebration.January  marks the beginning of the Christian holiday Epiphany.Superstition suggests it is "bad luck" to keep your decorationsup after this date.However last year many people around the country kept their Christmas lights up well into February to maintain some festive cheer during the post-Christmaslockdown.

title: scotland-v-moldova-channel-kick-off-time-watch-live-tv-tonight
story: Steve Clarkes side currently sit in second place with  points trailing Denmarkwho lead with  points.The top two teams from each group will qualy for the play-offs for the  Quatar World Cup anda win tonight will secure Scotlands second place finish.The pressure may be on, but Scotland can come into the match with confidence having won - against Moldova in September.Of course, that match was slightly closer than anticipated and took place in front of a home crowd whereas tonights match is at Zimbru stadium in Moldova.Regardless, Scotland will look to close the deal to take them once step closer to the World Cup dream.Heres what you need to know about tonights match and how you can tune in...Kick-off for Scotland v Moldova is at pm on Friday November .The match will take place at Zimbru stadium in Moldova, which is around a  hour flight from Scotland.The match will be broadcast live on Sky Sports, with subscribers able to stream the match throughthe Sky Go app.People who are not Sky customers can watch via NOWTV by buying a day pass for pound..Steve Clarke has named a -player strong squad for the World Cup Qualiers.Goalkeepers:Craig Gordon , Jon McLaughlin , Liam Kelly .Defenders:Stephen ODonnell , Nathan Patterson , Jack Hendry , Grant Hanley , Scott McKenna , Liam Cooper ,Kieran Tierney , Andy Robertson .Midfielders:Billy Gilmour , Kenny McLean , Callum McGregor , Stuart Armstrong Stev, David Turnbull , John McGinn , Lewis Ferguson , Scott McTominay .Strikers:Lyndon Dykes , Che Adams , Ryan Christie , Ryan Fraser , Kevin Nisbet .The starting line-up will be announced before the match later today.

title: scotland-v-denmark-kick-off-time-channel-watch-world-cup-qualifier
story: As it stands, Denmark leads Group F with  points while Scotland is in second place with ,  points ahead of Israel.Steve Clarkes side will play Moldova on Friday evening, and a win will mean they guarantee their qualication for the play-offs next year.If they can secure victory over Moldova, it will take the pressure off Scotland for their match against Denmark, who have gone unbeaten so far in the tournament.The top two teams in each group will progress tothe next stage of qualication, with the play-offs taking place in March .With full capacity crowds set toto Hampden Park on Monday night, heres what you need to know about Scotland v Denmark...Scotland will play Denmark at :pm on Monday November .The match will take place at Hampden Park, Glasgow, making it another home game for Scotland.The match will be broadcast live on Sky Sports, with subscribers able to stream the match throughthe Sky Go app.People who are not Sky customers can watch via NOWTV by buying a day pass for pound..Group F as it stands:Denmark:  pointsScotland:  pointsIsrael:  pointsAustria:  pointsFaroe Islands:  pointsMoldova:  pointThe play-offs will take place on March  and  .The World Cup in Quatar will start on Monday November  , taking place later in the year than usual due to the high summer temperatures in Doha.

title: scotland-v-south-africa-tv-channel-kick-off-scotland-rugby-match
story: Last week the team played against Australiain front of a home crowd, winning -in a close and dramatic match.Now turning their attention to South Africa, the odds looktipped in the latters favour, with the team having won the last six head-to-heads.However, Scotland comes off the back of two triumphs and with a home crowd behind them once again, the team will look to extend their successful run.South Africa arrive in Edinburgh following their -win over Wales last week, so regardless of the final outcome of Saturdays match,it looks set to beexciting.As rugby enthusiasts once again fill up the Edinburgh stadium, heres how you can watch at home...The Scotland v South Africa match will take place at Murrayfield on Saturday November at pm.It is Scotlands third game in the autumn series, which will take place throughout November.Amazon Prime hasthe broadcast rights for the autumn international series in the UK.You will need a membership to tune in, butyou dont already have one you can sign up to a -day free trial.If you dont want to continue your trial after the -days however, you will need to remember to cancel your subscription.Here is Scotlands schedule for the autumn series:Scotland v South Africa: Saturday November  at pmScotland v Japan: Saturday November  at pmThe Scotland team for Saturdays match is yet to be confirmed.Meanwhile, this was the line-up for last weeks match against Australia:Stuart HoggDarcy Graham, Chris Harris, Sam Johnson, Duhan van der Merwe Finn Russell, Ali Price Pierre Schoeman, George Turner, Zander Fagerson, Sam Skinner, Grant Gilchrist, Jamie Ritchie, Hamish Watson, Matt Fagerson.Replacements:Ewan Ashman, Jamie Bhatti, Oli Kebble, Jamie Hodgson, Josh Bayliss, George Horne, Adam Hastings, Kyle Steyn.

title: send-letters-santa-royal-mail-year--
story: Theres no need to try and sendletters up the chimney, just pop it in a post box instead.For -years, Royal Mail has been helping hundreds of thousands of children post their letters to Santa.Heres how you can send Santa letters this year...You can send your letters to Santa this year at the address:Santa Father Christmas,Santarsquos Grotto,Reindeerland,XM HQLetters should be sent by Friday December  to ensure time for response.Make sure to attachfull name and address so senders can receive a reply from Santa.The card from Santa will include a special note from the man himself and a recipe for a gingerbread Buddy the elf recipe.If you cant wait for the response, the card can be downloaded from the Royal Mail website.Royal Mail is encouraging customers to shop early and post early for Christmas this year.Its latest recommended posting dates for mail to arrive in time for Christmas are:Saturday  DecemberTuesday  DecemberThursday  December

title: covid-scotland-need-passenger-locator-form-return-uk
story: Before arriving in the UK, travellers must complete a form detailing where they have been and where they are travelling to.This applies to everyone coming to the UK from abroad, evenyou are only transiting through the country.Heres everything you need to know about filling in the form and travelling to the UK from abroad...You must complete a passenger locator form within-hours before travelling to the UK.Yoursquoll need to show thisform when you check in to travel or board your plane, train or ferry to the UK.If you have not filled out the form, you could be denied travel.The form asks for details of where you have been, vaccination status and where you are going.To complete the form yoursquoll need:You can fill out your passenger locator form here.England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland are following a four nationsapproach to international travel, meaning the rules for all four countries are the same.If you are fully vaccinatedyou are still required to take a test within two days of arrival in the UK, however this can now be a lateral flow test instead of a PCR test as previously required.Lateral flow tests are cheaper than PCR tests.If you are not fully vaccinated, you must take a test before travelling to the UK, book and pay for tests for day and day  after arrival and quarantine for  days.You will also be required to complete a passenger locator form.

title: runs-scotland-investigation-scotlands-corridors-power-full
story: Our subscribers will get exclusive access to the people and organisationswith signicant influence over so many aspects of our lives.From the hundreds of secret lobbying meetings to who really runs Scotlands wind farms, whisky and media - the investigation will leave no stone unturned in a bid to stimulate discussion and debate.Here, you can find every article published in the week-long investigation so far - with this piece being updated daily with new exclusive stories.To make sure you do not miss out on the high-quality insight, join us today by taking out a subscription for just pound for two months here.Hundreds of meetings between Scottish ministers and multinationals, wealthy iniduals and other influentialorganisationswere left off the lobbying register in  due to loopholes in legislation, The Ferret can reveal.Analysis of Scottish Government ministersrsquoengagements in shows that meetings, potentially of key public interest, were not in the register, including those between ministers andcompaniesawarded multi-million poundUK and Scottish contracts to supply the NHS in the run-up to Covid-.Read the full scale of unrecorded discussions here.Professional lobbyists, including former politicians, advisors and a former minister have met with Scottish Government representatives on behalf of clients  times since March , The Ferret can reveal.Scotlandis home to dozens of public relations, think-tanks and consultancy firms, including several formed by or employing people who served in the upper echelons of government.Find out the whos who of professional lobbyists here.Questions have been raised over the power and influence of energycompaniesfollowing analysis by The Ferret revealing how key sectors dominate Scottish lobbying.The Ferretcategorisedorganisationsthat lobbied Scottish Government ministers since the register was introduced in  to increase transparency.Read the full exclusive analysis here.Bigbusinessincluding oil and renewable energy, farming, fishing, finance and whisky dominated Scotland Office ministersrsquo meetings last year, analysis by The Ferret has found.We looked at all external meetings logged in  by Alister Jack, Secretary of State forScotland, UK Government ministers for Scotland David Duguid and Iain Stewart, as well as Scottish Tory leader Douglas Ross, who was deputy Secretary of State until he resigned in May that year.Read the full report exclusively here.The number ofcompaniesregistered in tax havens investing in Scotland over the last decade has increased by nearly  per cent.Analysis of Scottish Governmentdataby The Ferret found that in  there were  firms registered in the Cayman Islands, Bermuda and British Virgin Islands operating, compared to  in . Their collective turnover last year amounted to just over poundbn.Read the full exclusive story here.Nearly a third of Scotlandrsquos biggest wind farms have owners with links to offshore tax havens in the Cayman Islands, Luxembourg, Guernsey and Jersey.An investigation by The Ferret has also revealed that  of the largest  wind farms are ultimately ownedoutwithScotland in England, Spain, France, Germany, Norway, China and where.Read the full report here.Nearly  per cent of malt whisky distilleries are ultimately owned bycompaniesoutside Scotland with wealthy people linked to the industry including a French fashion billionaire, an Australian yoghurt tycoon, a Swiss philanthropist and Thailandrsquos richest man.The Ferret can reveal that of the Scots distilleries only a thirdare owned by Scottish firms.Read the full story here.Ten of Scotlands major newspapers are owned by just three men: Rupert Murdoch, Lord Rothermere and Frederick Barclay. They are all billionaires who, personally or through their businesses, have used thelawto avoid paying tax.An analysis by The Ferret reveals that all but one of Scotlands national newspapers, the Sunday Post, are owned in other countries.Read the full storyhereFive privatecompanieswho employ around three quarters of the workforce in Scotlandrsquos arms industry had thousands ofclosed doormeetings with the UK Government between  and .As part of TheFerretrsquosWho Runs Scotlandinvestigation we looked at firmsoperating in Scotlandrsquosdefenceindustry and examined data about them obtained by the Campaign Against Arms Trade .Read the full report here.The chief executives of quangos appointed by Scottish Government ministers were paid over poundm in total last year, leading to ldquoexcessive pay gaps between those at the top and lower paid public sector workers, The Ferret has found.In the course of ourresearchwe looked at the salaries ndash before bonuses or pension tops-up ndash of  leaders of quangos . There are just over  quangos in Scotland, which include Scottish governmentpublic andhealthbodies, executive agencies, non-ministerial offices and commissions.Read the full exclusive story here.Women board members appointed to Scotlandrsquos public bodies get paid half a million pounds less than their male counterparts, despite a drive for gender equality, The Ferret can reveal.Published pay arrangements for board members across  dferent public bodies, where appointments are largely overseen by the Scottish Government, show there are now virtually equal numbers of men and women serving on them.Read the full story here.Influential bankers,retired senior civil servants, well-connected industry insiders, powerful chief executives and former politicians - meet Scotlandrsquos quango class, the people who serve on the boards of Scotlandrsquos public bodies.Some roles are unpaid, and manyworkextra hours intheirdevotion to public service. But analysis by The Ferret of Scottish Government public board positionshas also found a web of influential connections binding many serving in the public sector.Read the full analysis here.So who runs Scotland  Thatrsquos been the central question of The Ferret and The Heraldrsquos week-long investigation.Along the way wersquove examined the corridors of power and looked at who gets the most access to ministers ndash and who doesnrsquot.Find out the top most influential people in Scotland here.Scotlandrsquos biggest private landowner has been attacked as ldquomanipulative and ldquoundemocratic after The Ferret revealed that his company lobbied the Scottish Government to stymie plans for a spaceport in Sutherland.A letter released under freedom of informationlawshows thatWildland Limitedmdash which runs three large estates acrossScotlandfor Danish billionaire,Anders Holch Povlsenmdash warned the former ruraleconomyminister, Fergus Ewing, that its planned investments could be endangered by the spaceport.Read the full story here.Scotlandneeds a radical sht in the way that power and influence are distributed to help address democratic deficits and rebuild trust in the political process, The Ferret has been told.Politicians and campaigners reacting to our week-long investigation ndash Who Runs Scotland ndash claimed it has revealed deep flaws in our transparency legislation and a heavy reliance on big businesses based outwith Scotland, including those with links to tax havens.Read the full final story here.

title: scottish-politics-features-covid-sign-newsletters
story: Weve been expanding our newsletter service here at The Herald, and we want to take you through our new and improved offerings.You can subscribe to our newslettersyoure a registered user or a subscriber by heading to our sign up page and selecting your favourites.Every day, were giving you a rundown of who you can expect in our incredible Voices section.We go through the columnists of the day, giving a sneak peek into their musings - and well also showcase the fantastic illustrations from our in-house artist, Steven Camley, as well.In April, we launched a new evening political newsletter, Unspun, which promises readers an exclusive analysis of the day in Scottish politics - and a look at whats coming next.As Scotland deals with the aftermath of what was one of the most important Scottish elections in history, were bringing you top insight from some of our most popular contributors every weekday at pm.Wersquove enlisted the help of Alison Rowat on Tuesdays, Kevin McKenna on Wednesdays, Iain Macwhirter on Thursdays and Neil Mackay on Fridays.For all the latest coronavirus news in Scotland, including the latest figures and updates, make sure you subscribe to our Covid in Scotland newsletter, reaching inboxes at pm each day.Youll be given the latest figures in Scotland, and have all the latest news and analysis about the pandemic from our health correspondents at your fingertips.At pm, well take you through the stories our readers have been enjoying the most from that day.Well give you a rundown of the headlines and a preview of the pieces that have been getting our readers talking in our catch-up newsletter - perfect for your commute home.In addition to politics, fans of Scotlands arts and cultural scene are set to benefit from our brand new Herald Magazine newsletter, reaching inboxes every Saturday at pm.Written by assistant editor Garry Scott and senior features writer Susan Swarbrick, youll get the latest from our weekly Saturday magazine straight to your inbox, and our top picks from the pages.So sit back, relax, and get the latest straight to your inbox everyday by signing up here

title: green-scotland-can-read-investigation
story: From big-name polluters to Scotlandrsquos most deteriorating rivers and lochs, The Heraldrsquos exclusive, week-long investigation kicks off on Tuesday, October , to answer some of the crucial questions in the ongoing climate crisis.Hot off the back of the successfullsquoWho Runs Scotland rsquo series in July, no stone will be left unturned in The Herald and The Ferretrsquos joint bid to uncover wrongdoing, stimulate debate, and generate discussion.This special series will run in print and online all of this week, exclusively to our subscribers.To make sure you do not miss out on the high-quality insight, join us today.

story: Steve Clarkes side currently sit in second place with  points trailing Denmarkwho lead with  points.The top two teams from each group will qualy for the play-offs for the  Quatar World Cup anda win tonight will secure Scotlands second place finish.The pressure may be on, but Scotland can come into the match with confidence having won - against Moldova in September.Of course, that match was slightly closer than anticipated and took place in front of a home crowd whereas tonights match is at Zimbru stadium in Moldova.Regardless, Scotland will look to close the deal to take them once step closer to the World Cup dream.Heres what you need to know about tonights match and how you can tune in...Kick-off for Scotland v Moldova is at pm on Friday November .The match will take place at Zimbru stadium in Moldova, which is around a  hour flight from Scotland.The match will be broadcast live on Sky Sports, with subscribers able to stream the match throughthe Sky Go app.People who are not Sky customers can watch via NOWTV by buying a day pass for pound..Steve Clarke has named a -player strong squad for the World Cup Qualiers.Goalkeepers:Craig Gordon , Jon McLaughlin , Liam Kelly .Defenders:Stephen ODonnell , Nathan Patterson , Jack Hendry , Grant Hanley , Scott McKenna , Liam Cooper ,Kieran Tierney , Andy Robertson .Midfielders:Billy Gilmour , Kenny McLean , Callum McGregor , Stuart Armstrong Stev, David Turnbull , John McGinn , Lewis Ferguson , Scott McTominay .Strikers:Lyndon Dykes , Che Adams , Ryan Christie , Ryan Fraser , Kevin Nisbet .The starting line-up will be announced before the match later today.

title: glasgow-city-centre-new-car-free-zone-announced
story: A core area restricted to public transport will becreated withinthe next five years,stretching from George Squareto pollution hot spot Hope Street across Argyle Street and up to Cathedral Street.The council leader said poundbn will be spent over the next ten years to help achieve an ambitious target of net zero living by .She said the council had already taken some "tough decisions" around pollution and congestion including Scotlands first Low Emissions Zoneand said it wanted to take this a step further.She said: "Over the coming days we are going to announce that we have designated a core of our historic city centre from George Square, over to Hope Street where Central Station is, from Cathedral Street to the north to Argyle Street to the south and work towards that being a space entirely free of private cars over the next five years - obviously with caveats for disabled access.: Edinburgh to scale back low emission zone plans"This core of Glasgow city centre will be given over entirely to public transport and to people moving actively," said Ms Aitken."Its a big step and we dont under-estimate the challenge of making that transition from what has been for far too long a private car dominated city centre."It is something that will have to be delivered in partnership with city centre businesses, which is why we will do it incrementally over the next five years or so."But I think its the kind of ambition that we have to demonstrate. We have to move beyond doing this partially and do it on a bigger sale."We need new ideas, a new vision and collaborations to create that better and sustainable le that we envision for everyone in Glasgow."Friends of the Earth Scotland welcomed the plan saying it was a "great step forward for Glasgow in the urgent task of reducing climate emissions".However, Stuart Patrick, Chief Executive of Glasgow Chamber of Commerce, said he was extremely disappointedthat there was "no consultation" with business and the wider community ahead of todaysannouncement.: Glasgow city centre castles in the sky providing a quiet le for residentsHe said there was a need for data and evidence to back up the plan, "otherwise this risks becoming a gimmick policy".Christy Mearns, Green councillor for the city centre, said the proposals must be "as ambitious as possible" but said it was crucial that they were progressed alongside a robust plan to improve public transport affordability and connectivity.He said this should include the exploration of a free, electric shuttle bus service into the city centre.European cities with large, car-free areas in their centres include Brussels, Copenhagen and Munich.In Oslo, most on-street parking has been replaced with street furniture like benches and mini parks, as well as bike lanes and bigger pavements. Though some businesses feared a loss of trade, the city centre is said to have reported a  per cent rise in footfall after the reduction measures.In Northern Spain, the city of Pontevedra banned cars from its , square metre medieval centre in the early s, leading to a  per cent drop inCO emissions.Ms Aitken made the announcement during a public event which aimedto promotethe leading role cities mustplay in the climate emergency.She said Glasgowwas already taking forward major initiativesincluding theroll-out of the Avenues Programme, which is re-designing city centre streets to promote active travel and has transformed the lower part of Sauchiehall Street.: Scotlands most polluted streets exposed"Weve already taken some tough decisions around pollution and congestion including Scotlands first low emissions zone which will remove all but the greenest vehicles by ," she said."Our Spaces for People projectwas a major response to Covid as the city re-opened after lockdown to re-prioritise public space and give it to people rather than cars."Phase of Glasgows low emissions zone applies to local servicebuses only, however all vehicles entering the city centre zone will be required tomeet the required emission standards to avoid a penalty unless the vehicle isexempt whenPhase  is enforced from June  .David Lonsdale, Director of theScottish Retail Consortium said the latest figures showed shopping footfall in the city centre was down .% last month and said "easy and affordable" parking was essential to support retailers.Stuart Patrick, chief executive of Glasgow Chamber of Commerce, said: ldquoWe are extremely disappointed that there was no prior consultation with business and the wider community before this announcement which,implemented, will ban private cars from large swathes of the city centre.ldquoThis proposal has not been discussed at the City Centre Taskforce nor was it part of the Councilrsquos own Connectivity Commission which was endorsed by the Chamber and presented a clear transport plan for Glasgow city centre.ldquoMany of the infrastructure proposals set out by the Connectivity Commission, which was led by data and evidence and designed to improve pedestrian experience, have yet to be delivered ndash for example, the full completion of the Avenues programme.ldquoBefore the city embarks on large scale traffic bans, we need to see the data and evidence that supports this proposal, otherwise this risks becoming a gimmick policy.ldquoAs people and businesses are only too aware, Glasgow city centre is still struggling to recover from the pandemic, and this could be a further blow to the overall economic health of the city centre and the need to support jobs and investment."ldquoBusiness is acutely conscious of a just transition to net-zero, but we need policies that that support climate change, not simply blocking access to the hard-pressed city centre and sending customers where. ldquoMore than ever, we need to be encouraging people to come into Glasgow City Centre, not drive them away. There needs to be a constructive dialogue with business and full consultation before any large-scale traffic bans are carried forward.Hisashi Kuboyama,Federation of Small Businesses development manager for Glasgow, said some businesses might have concerns about staff travel or deliveries.He said: "Civic decision-makers have a duty to listen to local firms, take on board fresh ideas or alternative suggestions. Everyone wants Glasgow city centre to remain a great place to do business, but to do that the council will need to genuinely engage with local firms.Professor John Lennon, Director of theMoffat Centrefor Travel and Tourism Business Development at Glasgow Caledonian University said the plans must consider the effecton retail and tourism.He said: "Obviously in this period of COP we recognise the need to make changes in the way we live our lives but Glasgow has been peculiarly negatively impacted from Covid, more so than other cities across the UK - its faily well agreed so before we start initiatives like this we need to ensure we help with the recovery."It should be a joint policy with joint consensus. We dont get anywhere by springing surprises on people."It comes after an investigation by The Ferretfound almost a third of Scotlandrsquos streets have higher levels of toxic particle air pollution than they did before the Covid- pandemic.The ldquoappalling findings show the levels of air pollution caused by small particles ndash known as particulate matter and#largely due to traffic pollution ndash increased in  per cent of average readings taken this year, when compared with data from .The readings looked at levels of two of the most common pollutants ndash#nitrogen dioxide and PM ndash#which can both have serious health implications, particularly for those with underlying health conditions.Glasgowrsquos Hope Street was the only one still breaching legal limits in the  data under this measure.Prior to  it had broken legal air pollution limits for nine consecutive years. However, thesix monthly average in  was lower than in any year apart from  for a decade.#

title: cop26-glasgow-road-closures-full-streets-re-open-weekend
story: COP has caused a headache for many Glasgow motorists over the last few weeks. The Clyde Expressway has been shut for nearly three weeks and drivers have faced major ersions, some as long as five miles.However, the road closures are now approaching an end and the first street willre-open this Saturday.The road between Minerva Street andWest Greenhill Place will re-open from am this Saturday, but the more major Glasgow roads which have caused signicant travel disruption will remain closed until Monday.:Glasgow city centre new car free zone announcedMonday will see the Clyde Expressway and M junction  at Anderston back open for public use. The three mile stretch of dual carriageway which usually has thousands of vehicles pass through every day will help ease congestion on the M.There are also several other roads re-opening in Glasgow onNovember , and other closures will finish throughout the week with the final road re-opening on November .

title: scotland-vs-south-africa---springbok-prop-ox-nche-shares-cake-quest-ahead-test-match
story: The Springboks prop, who will pack down opposite Zander Fagerson tomorrow when his team take on Scotland at Murrayfield, appeared a touch worried when he answered questions at a press conference on Wednesday. The cause of his concern: he did not know where his next slice of cake was coming from.With little time to explore an unfamiliar city, the -year-old - whose real first name is Retshegofaditswe - said he had recruited a South African broadcaster to help him out. ldquoI havenrsquot gone out to explore some cake places, but Matthew Pearce has said he has organised some good quality cake for me, Nche explained. ldquoIrsquoll let you know tomorrow. Chocolate caramel would be great, but Irsquoll settle for vanilla as well.True to his word, the forward reported back yesterday via his Twitter account, posting a photo of himself holding a big slice of cake. ldquoLadies and gentlemen, the cake has landed, he announced. ldquoI repeat, THE CAKE HAS LANDED!Such lighthearted moments help pass the time between matches for players whose movements are still restricted by Covid concerns, although needless to say, Nche will be in an altogether more serious mood when he takes the field tomorrow. He got the better of the front-row battle in his teamrsquos win over Wales last week, but does not expect to have things all his own way against the Scots.ldquoHonestly, itrsquos a dferent kind of battle, he said. ldquoTheir [scrum] coach is Pieter de Villiers. I worked with him in my under- and SA schools and I know hersquos a pretty good coach. You can see that from how well they did against Australia.ldquoWersquore expecting a dferent challenge. They do have some pride in their set piece and their maul. Theyrsquove gotten a lot of reward from their scrums and mauls, so wersquore expecting a good challenge there. Wersquoll see how we man up to the challenge.Nche will be up against a Scotland front row that includes South African-born Pierre Schoeman, but he insisted that the country of origin of his opponents would not make any dference to his determination to win. ldquoWe have a goal to achieve this weekend against their entire pack, he said. ldquoYou have eight South Africans against eight Scottish guys: we donrsquot see it as seven Scottish guys and Pierre.

title: green-scotland-cop26-climate-investigation-full
story: Our subscribers will get exclusive accessas we look to answer the pressing questions in Scotlands climate crisis fight.As the COP conference looms on the horizon, we will leave no stone unturned in a bid to stimulate discussion and debate on this crucial topic.Find out more about our exclusive pound for two months offer here.From the hundreds of sites and big-name companies that broke environmental rules, to the most polluted streets in Scotland, readers can expectground-breaking exclusives, in-depth analysis, and interactive content ndash as well as regular live videos, giving you the chance to speak directly with the award-winning reporters behind the stories.Here, you can find every article published in the week-long investigation so far - with this piece being updated daily with new exclusive stories.To make sure you do not miss out on the high-quality insight, join us today by taking out a subscription for just pound for two monthshere.More than  industrial sites across Scotland have been officially damned as ldquounsatisfactory on pollution, according to data from the ScottishEnvironmentProtection Agencyseen by The Ferret.Sepa assessed the environmental performance of two big oilcompanies, ExxonMobil and Ineos, as ldquovery poor in . A Grangemouth chemical plant and a Coupar Angus chicken processor were rated as ldquopoor.Read the full exclusive report here.More than one in ten of Scotlandrsquos fish farms have been rated as ldquounsatisfactory" by the Scottish Governmentrsquos environmental watchdog because of pollution, pesticide and reporting breaches, wecan today reveal.The ScottishEnvironmentProtection Agencyhas assessed over  of some  salmon farms around the coast as either ldquovery poor, ldquopoor or ldquoat risk because they broke, or threatened to break, environmental rules in .The exclusive revelations can be read here in full.WE can today reveal the top sitesacrossScotland that have been officiallydeemed "unsatisfactory" on pollution by Scotlands environmental watchdog.The ScottishEnvironmentProtection Agencydamnedthe performance of more than  sitesincluding Trump Turnberry, Ineos, and Faslane nuclear base.View the full interactive map of sites here.More than , of Scotlands wildle species and natural habitats are in a "poor" condition, and dozens of the nationrsquos protected sites have been damaged byclimate change, we can reveal.Ahead of the COP conference in Glasgow, our joint investigation with The Ferret reveals that  habitats and  species inScotlandare in poor condition. We also found that climate change has impacted  protected sites and  natural features.Read the full exclusive report here.DOZENS of Scotlands protected sites have been damaged byclimate change, we canreveal today.The long term decline of Scotlandrsquos wildle was documented in a report in  called the State of Nature which claimed one in nine species - including kittiwakes and wildcats - was threatened with extinction.View the full map here.MORE than  habitats and  species inScotlandare in "poor" condition, we can reveal.Environmental and wildle groups are calling for urgent action to combat the twinclimate changeand wildle crises and help preserve Scotlandrsquos natural heritage.View the list in full here.Almost a third of Scotlandrsquos streets have higher levels of toxic particle air pollution than they did before the Covid- pandemic, analysis can reveal.#The ldquoappalling findings show the levels of air pollution caused by small particles ndash known as particulate matter and#largely due to traffic pollution ndash increased in  per cent of average readings taken this year, when compared with data from .View the full exclusive report here.Air pollution is to be the subject of a Scotland-wide investigation ndash the first to be carried out by the countrys new environmental watchdog, we can reveal.EnvironmentStandards Scotland , an independent body which came into force on  October to oversee environmental law post-Brexit, confirmed the "intractable issue" which has plagued Scotland for ldquoover a decade would be the focus of its first major piece of work.Read the full story here.The traffic is at a standstill on Atholl Street in the centre of Perth, cars, trucks and buses running their engines as they wait for the lights to change.##For years this city street ndash#with its mixture of shops, cafes and homes ndash#has been amongst Scotlandrsquos most polluted due to levels of particulate matter . Nitrogen dioxide readings are as high as many on the streets of Scotlandrsquos biggest cities. Exposure to high levels of both pollutants has been linked to increased risk ofhealthconditions like asthma, strokes and even dementia.#Read the full case study here.In an open letter to the First Minister, Nicola Sturgeon, published as part of our joint investigation, over  leadinghealthprofessionals ndash including consultants, GPs and medical academics ndash are calling for more action to be taken on air pollution to save lives.Councils must enforce laws, they say, air monitoring should be increased, including outside schools, while the Scottish Government should invest more heavily in active travel, publictransportand green infrastructure.Read the letter in full here.Scotlandrsquos rivers, lochs, canals and burns are in the worst state on record, with more than  damaged by pollution and other problems, according to the latest official analysis.New assessment methods used by the ScottishEnvironmentProtection Agencyhave more than doubled the number of waterways classied as ldquobad between  and . There are ldquosignicant environmental problems caused by a number of pressures, Sepa said.Read the full exclusive report here.SCOTLANDS worst rivers, lochs, canals and burns for pollution have been revealed in new analysis of official watchdog data.Amongst the many rivers rated as either bad or poor by Sepa are some of Scotlandrsquos most well-known. They include long stretches of the Almond, Carron, Dee, Don, Earn, Esk, Kelvin, Lossie, Nairn, Nith, Spey, Tay, Tummel, and Water of Leith.Find how your local river or loch ranks using our interactive toolNearly  sites run by Scottish Water including sewage and wastewater treatment are ldquopoor, ldquovery poor or ldquoat risk, according to Scotlandrsquos environmental watchdog.Almost all these ldquounsatisfactory sites are considered to be among Scotlandrsquos critical national infrastructure ndash operations deemed essential for the state to deliver vital public services.Read the full story here.Today, we reveal the Scottish Government has missed its targets on reducing climate emissions in five of the seven sectors set out in its  plan to tackle climate change.Environmental activists said the missed targets painted a ldquodisappointing picture of widespread failure on emissions reductions. They worry that static or increasing annual emissions in key sectors mean Scotland risks squandering good progress made in other areas.Read the full exclusive report here.The Scottish Government must take ldquoradical action on green job creation and ending fuel povertyit is to achieve a Just Transition to net-zero carbon emissions, trade unions sayThe Scottish low carbon economy provided , jobs in , the most recent data available, a nearly five per cent decrease from . It was also fewer than the , roles provided by the sector in .Read the story in full here.

title: blues festival comeback postponed
story: coronavirusBlues Festival comeback postponedNovember ,  at : pmPlans by Orkney Blues Festival to bring a weekend of live music to Stromness, this November, have been postponed.The Blues Festival committee confirmed the decision, taken due to Orkney’s current situation with COVID-, this Wednesday evening.In a statement, the committee said: “After careful discussion and guidance, the Orkney Blues Festival committee has decided to postpone next week’s eventin light of the current COVID- situation within the county.“The health and safety of our community and festival attendees is our top priority and we feel it would be unwise to go ahead at the present time.“We aim to share a revised date with you very soon and all purchased tickets will be refunded. Please message the OBF Facebookyou have any queries.“As ever we thank you for your continued support of the festival and live music in Orkney.“Stay safe and we will see you all very soon.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: cookie policy
story: Cookie PolicyWhat Are CookiesAs is common practice with almost all professional websites this site uses cookies, which are tiny files that are downloaded to your computer, to improve your experience. This page describes what information they gather, how we use it and why we sometimes need to store these cookies. We will also share how you can prevent these cookies from being stored however this may downgrade or #break# certain elements of the sites ality.For more general information on cookies see the Wikipedia article on HTTP Cookies.How We Use CookiesWe use cookies for a iety of reasons detailed below. Unfortunately in most cases there are no industry standard options for disabling cookies without completely disabling the ality and features they add to this site. It is recommended that you leave on all cookiesyou are not sure whether you need them or not in case they are used to provide a service that you use.Disabling CookiesYou can prevent the setting of cookies by adjusting the settings on your browser . Be aware that disabling cookies will affect the ality of this and many other websites that you visit. Disabling cookies will usually result in also disabling certain ality and features of the this site. Therefore it is recommended that you do not disable cookies.The Cookies We SetWe use cookies when you are logged in so that we can remember this fact. This prevents you from having to log in every single time you visit a new page. These cookies are typically removed or cleared when you log out to ensure that you can only access restricted features and areas when logged in.From time to time we offer user surveys and questionnaires to provide you with interesting insights, helpful tools, or to understand our user base more accurately. These surveys may use cookies to remember who has already taken part in a survey or to provide you with accurate results after you change pages.When you submit data to through a form such as those found on contact pages or comment forms cookies may be set to remember your user details for future correspondence.In order to provide you with a great experience on this site we provide the ality to set your preferences for how this site runs when you use it. In order to remember your preferences we need to set cookies so that this information can be called whenever you interact with a page is affected by your preferences.Third Party CookiesIn some special cases we also use cookies provided by trusted third parties. The following section details which third party cookies you might encounter through this site.This site uses Google Analytics which is one of the most widespread and trusted analytics solution on the web for helping us to understand how you use the site and ways that we can improve your experience. These cookies may track things such as how long you spend on the site and the pages that you visit so we can continue to produce engaging content.For more information on Google Analytics cookies, see the official Google Analytics page.Third party analytics are used to track and measure usage of this site so that we can continue to produce engaging content. These cookies may track things such as how long you spend on the site or pages you visit which helps us to understand how we can improve the site for you.The Google AdSense service we use to serve advertising uses a DoubleClick cookie to serve more relevant ads across the web and limit the number of times that a given ad is shown to you.For more information on Google AdSense see the official Google AdSense privacy FAQ.More InformationHopefully that has claried things for you and as was previously mentionedthere is something that you aren#t sure whether you need or not it#s usually safer to leave cookies enabled in case it does interact with one of the features you use on our site.Howeveryou are still looking for more information then you can contact us through one of our preferred contact methods.Email: support@orcadianPhone:  copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. Reg No. – SC Registered Office: Hell’s Half Acre, Hatston, Kirkwall, Orkney, KW GJ

title: covid forces partial closure of papdale primary
story: Papdale Nursery will be closed tomorrow, while Papdale Primary School will be running at a reduced service, Orkney Islands Council has confirmed this Sunday evening.The decision has been taken due to signicantly reduced staffing levels and a stretched teaching supply list as a result of COVID-. This change will take effect from Monday, November  until at least Wednesday, November .Infection among both pupils and staff at the school have mounted in recent days. As of this evening  pupils have been confirmed as COVID-positive, along with five members of staff. A further four members of staff have recorded positive lateral flow test results.As a result, the nursery has been forced to close entirely, while four primary classes will remain home.The classes to close from Monday to Wednesday are: PM, PE. Classes PE and PM are to close on Monday only at this time. Online learning will be offered to affected pupils.According to a statement released by OIC, this evening, the situation will remain under daily review andthe position changes, parents and staff will be updated.The remainder of classes at Papdale Primary School will be open on Monday as usual.James Wylie, OIC’s executive director of education, leisure and housing said: “Staff have been working tirelessly over the last week to try and ensure Papdale Primary and Nursery were able to remain open in full, however, this has now reached the point where it is simply no longer possible. There are several factors for this including staff reporting positive PCR test results, being contact traced by Public Health, and the supply teaching staff list having been exhausted.“We realise that this may cause childcare issues for working parents and that is partly why we will keep the closures to an absolute minimum and monitor and manage the situation on a daily basis, ensuring that the settings are able to reopen once it is safe to do so with the appropriate staffing levels in place. It is also vital that we keep our educational facilities open whenever possible for the learning of our children, who have already missed out on so much these past  months of the pandemic.“I, again, take this opportunity to thank our staff, parents and pupils for the way in which we all continue to manage these situations, which are challenging for everyone. We must all continue to do our bit to try and stem the transmission of the virus, which is undoubtedly here for some time to come. This is now about learning to manage how we live, work and learn with COVID-. Please continue to follow the guidance, which is outlined by our colleagues at NHS Orkney below.”According to NHS Orkney, around one in three people with COVID- don’t show any symptoms.The health authority believes it is more important than ever to take your two free COVID lateral flow tests every week and record your results, evenyou are fully vaccinated and don#t have symptoms.Lateral flow test kits can be collected from community pharmacies and local test sites or ordered online at nhsinform.scot testing.  You can access the direct link to order LFD tests here: https:www.gov.uk order-coronavirus-rapid-lateral-flowRecording both positive and negative results allows NHS Orkney Public Health to track the presence of the virus in our communities.Find out more at nhsinform.scot testingIf you, or anyone in your household is displaying symptoms of COVID, or you have a positive lateral flow testyou must self-isolate immediately and book a PCR test in Orkney by calling  .A reminder of the ways we stay safe and protect ourselves and others against COVID are:copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co.
